reviewText: A modified version of The House of the Dead: Overkill in which you kill zombies (Sorry, I mean mutants) by typing words, how can it get any more awesome than that? It's based on the Extended Cut version of the game, which means it has redone graphics and two extra levels when compared to the original Wii release. If you get bored of typing, you can also play the entire shooting version of the game, which works pretty differently, meaning you basically get two games for the price of one.\n\nIt must be said that the typing side of the game isn't nearly as interesting or unique as the original Typing of the Dead, boss fights don't have fun gimmicks like answering questions correctly or being forced not to make any errors, and the difficulty remains pretty low through the whole game, even on the hardest difficulty, while in the original it was adjusted depending on how well you were doing. Still heavily recommended, just try to play the original as well somehow, because it's definitely better.

reviewText:
In The Typing of the Dead: Overkill you play as a special agent who partners up with a potty-mouthed detective to track down the villain Papa Ceasar and save the county from a mutant outbreak.  The story unfolds over nine episodes and combines horror with potentially disturbing, over-the-top comedy.

The game is a reworked version of the first-person rail shooter The House of the Dead: Overkill - Extended Cut, in which the shooting mechanics of combat have been replaced by quickly and accurately typing words and phrases that appear on screen.  Words are randomly chosen, so they are different every time you play, and multiple difficulty levels are available to provide a challenge for typists of varying skill levels.

A port of the Playstation 3 version of House of the Dead: Overkill - Extended Cut is also included so, if you type exclusively with your index fingers or simply don’t enjoy the activity, you can always take out zombies the old-fashioned way.  In this mode, you must aim and shoot traditionally and may buy and upgrade guns after each episode with the cash you were quick enough to grab.

Movement and camera are on pre-determined paths so the experience feels like taking a ride through a haunted house at the fair, allowing you to focus on destroying zombies, picking up collectibles, rescuing civilians and racking up your high score.  Boss fights at the end of each episode are well-designed and two-player co-op is a lot of fun, but it is possible to frequently encounter bugs in multiplayer that require you to restart the episode, such as words not appearing properly or the game desyncing and freezing.

Since the game involves dialogue littered with profanity (F bombs), plenty of gore, and touches on themes like incest and making fun of the handicapped, it’s not for the squeamish or those who may be offended by such things.  If you don’t take your entertainment too seriously and can handle the outrageous content, it’s very much worth the quick, three-to-four-hour playthrough, but no one would blame you if you couldn’t.

reviewText:
Typing of The Dead: Overkill is a game where you kill zombies by typing, it is based on the zombie game House of the Dead: Overkill.
Gameplay is simple and straightforward. Your point of view moves through the game world automatically, all you have to do is type every word that floats into view in order to kill the zombies. About capitalization, spaces, or punctuation you do not have to worry. How fast the zombies in front of you will attack is indicated by the colour surrounding the words.
The words that pop up are randomised, so each player's experience of the game is unique.
The storyline is presented cinematically with film scratches, a psychedelic intermission" screen when data is being loaded. Each of the 9 chapters arrive with a movie trailer voiceover that perfectly captures the spirit of the cheap golden age of bad movies.
Besides of the normal game mode there is a little arcade mode of mini-games where you can try out a survival mode with forever-spawning waves of zombies. The game also comes with the full version of the House of the Dead: Overkill
date:
so you can play through it with mouse or controller if you want.
The game can also be played cooperatively.
The graphics are bad. The textures and models look pretty miserably when you are playing.
The sound and dialogues can be really annoying after a while.
However
recommended:
I think criticising it for being ugly is to miss the point. The game is funny with hilarious characters and overall an enjoyable game that I would recommend if you want to improve your typing ability.

Sounds 6/10
Graphics 5/10
Gameplay 8/10
Atmosphere 7/10

If you liked my review

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: The Typing of The Dead: Overkill
Original Release: 2013 (2000)
Genre Tags: Innovative; Abstract; Zombies; Comedic; On-Rails-Shooter; Nostalgic; Typing
My Overall Grade: B+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 10-18 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Optional
Recommended To: Novelty seekers; Nostalgia chasers; Casual gamers
REVIEWThe Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a downright riot.  I loved the hilarious, cheesy B-movie dialogue and the nonsensical story.  And the gameplay itself was various, different, and entertaining.

The story isn’t written that seriously and the dialogue fits perfectly with intentional cheesy lines and some just plain hilarious writing.  I played through the game a total of 4 times (for achievements) and I found myself watching the cutscenes -almost- every time because they just entertained me that much.  The voice acting was pretty good overall; even when it faltered, it still fit the overall ambiance of the game anyway.

The typing mode is the selling point of the game.  It definitely provided me with a novel experience; I don’t think I have played a game with a mechanic like there is in this before. The original Typing of the Dead came out in 1999, but I had never played anything like it until now.  I enjoyed it a lot.  Playing on hard, with DLC and/or workshop content can make it a lot of fun with various hilarious things to type out as fast as you can without making a mistake.

The classic mode was also enjoyable to me.  It is an on-rails shooter, staying true to the original, light-gun arcade style.  It definitely brought on some nostalgia playing it.

Staying true to the hilarious, light-hearted nature of the game it is not difficult at all.  You have unlimited continues, so even if you mess up you just keep going (and don’t even have to drop in another quarter).  There is no backtracking required too.

The graphics were not the best, but it’s mostly intentional:  there is supposed to be an old-school, drive-in, grindhouse feel to the game.  However one thing that isn't intentional and occurs on a lot of user’s systems is that random parts of the models (an arm, both arms, the head, all of the above) of the mutant-zombies will pop in and out… and this did occur in my game too.  It didn’t really bother me that much in the typing mode because I was focused on the sentences, but in the classic mode it was a little disappointing shooting at invisible, un-rendered mutant-zombie heads.  There may even be ways to fix it depending on your system, but you will have to look into that yourself.

If you are a gamer who is looking for a taste of something different and novel, or a taste of something from ghosts of arcades past, this game has an offering of both.  With the available workshop content the typing mode has limitless possibilities.  Mix all that with some hilarious scenes, and homage to cheesy, horror B-movies and you get a just simply entertaining experience.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
This game not only promotes accurate typing and correct spelling but does so with the penalty of a fate worse than death. Failure! Yes, it's surprising what nonsense you can type above your ability when being run down by vile creatures of the dead, the game even goes as far to include punctuation which can be horrific when stringing together oddities. None the less this is a great brain workout and has an inspiring cheesy storyline that will have you laughing and reeling in revolution all the same.

The game was all I expected it to be and more with a brilliant sound track and clever writing/character development. It does not disappoint one little bit!

reviewText:
What else can be said that hasn't already been said?

This game is intentionally offensive and occasionally sexist, however only so much so as to imitate grindhouse-style cinema. If you're a sheltered delicate snowflake, this game is not for you; and it certainly isn't for children.

However, if you can look past those things, or you even enjoy those things, you'll like this game.

While I'd recommend picking this up on sale, it must be restated that it also includes a full port of the PS3 version of HOTD: Overkill; so even if you dislike typing mechanics and it's on sale for fairly cheap (as it is at the time of writing this), you may want to give it a go anyway.


Extra notes:
Graphics options are fairly limited: gamma, set resolutions, windowed mode and anti-aliasing are available.

HOTD supports both mouse and controller input, but with no rebindable keys.

You can invite a friend to play multiplayer, or search for another online player.

For multiplayer, there don't seem to be any sort of game listings and I don't know if it restricts games you can join based on how far in the game you are.

reviewText:
The next typing educational software to be introduced to schools ladies and gentlemen! Joke joke, not enough gore to reach the blood on screen requirements they have.

This game is really fun and at the same time extremely corny. The over the top humor is going to be a huge hit or miss on people but thats not going to make people drop the deal to get this game.

I am not sure if this game is something that could teach you how to type fast since it seems more like a testament to how fast you can already type because of previous courses you took or just pure experience. If you want to get this game on the whole idea of learning to type you might want to play this in sessions like 30 minutes to 1 hour a day and not overplay it so that it has more long term value and feels less reptitive to you. If your a keyboard warrior and just want to enjoy mowing down zombies with your skills then why not?

You never know though, I am sure this has helped some people out.

reviewText:
A fantastic B-Movie remake of the much older Typing of the Dead, which was orignally based on the House of the dead 2 game by SEGA. With a hilarious B-movie story line with great dialogue to boot, I definitely thoroughly enjoyed this game. I orignally purchased it in order to learn how to touch type and to improve my typing skills in general, and it has definitely accomplished just that. It is also a fantastic to way to break into a new keyboard, like I did with my Corsair RGB K70.

Not only does it have the Typing of the Dead, it also has game modes available for using the mouse to shoot, just like in the original House of the Dead franchise. Following the same B-movie storyline, it offers an extended Director's Cut mode with some additonal challenges for the more hardcore achievement hunters.
Check out my guide to completing the final achievement here.

Pros:+ Hilarious B-movie plot line with fantastic dialogue
+ A great host of characters and bosses
+ Greatly improves your touch typing skills
+ Helps to break in new keyboards
+ Also contains traditonal click-to-shoot game mode
+ Custom dictionaries available on the workshop for movie quotes, improving your touch typing skills, or even C# coding. You can even make your own!
+ Tough achievements for those who love a good challenge (I certainly do!)

Cons:- Some graphical glitches when you kill the zombies occasionally, however they can be quite amusing
- Sometimes in the click-to-shoot mode, zombies hit you  before you even reach them
- Has a rare problem when starting up the game where it keeps rebooting itself.

My Score: 8/10

reviewText:
When I first got this game, I kinda knew what to expect.  I'd played House of the Dead in the arcades, and I liked the idea of incorporating typing into the popular rail shooter.  I played it for a while, had fun, laughed at the stupid jokes and extreme over-acting of it all, and then pretty much shelved it for awhile.

A few days ago, I got my first mechanical keyboard (Corsair K65 RGB, Cherry MX Reds).  Then I remembered I owned this game, so I redownloaded it and I can honestly say that this game went from kinda fun to EXTREMELY fun.

With mechanical keys, my average score in the game is around 91%.  Definitely a different experience.  I almost wanna say you won't have any real fun in this unless 1) You love typing, and 2) You have a badass mechanical keyboard to play it.

As for the game itself, if you've ever played a rail shooter before, it's pretty standard.  Game moves on its own, zombies come at you and instead of using a light gun, you use your keyboard and type the words, terms, or sentences below the zombies.  Type it out correctly, and you kill the zombie.  Do it quick enough and you'll get a headshot.

If there are multiple zombies on screen, it'll use red arrows and a flashing border around the word to let you know you should dispatch THIS zombie first, or you'll get slapped.

The game mixes it up a lot.  Some zombies will throw stuff at you, and rather than concentrate on the word below them, you wanna shoot the single letter attached to the object flying at your face, and THEN take the zombie out.

Some words, terms, and sentences are longer than others, especially if you have some of the dictionary DLCs installed.  Also, get in the habit of hitting TAB periodically, as there are various green health packs, slow-mo power ups, game music tracks, and game artwork that can be collected.

The jokes are over-the-top, the monsters are disgustingly awesome, and my typing score is getting better and better.  Grab it up.

reviewText:
Before I start, these are just my impressions from a very Casual point of view. I had no interest in seeking any sort of challenge as this is the perfect game to play in short bursts after a long tiresome day. Each act is rather short so it won’t take you much time to complete meaning that, if you just ended a long, busy day, if you are dead tired or just want a mindless game without the need to focus a lot on Story elements or harsh gameplay mechanics, this game might be just what you need.

In Typing of the Dead you play in a Story where two characters who appear to have nothing in common must join forces to defeat a biggest problem than their own personality: Papa Caesar. Responsible (or is it…?) for the outbreak filled with Zombies from all sorts of sizes and horrible habits and for the murder (or maybe not…?) of one of character’s father death, you must play through 9 exciting Acts coming to you in a cheap Hollywood horror movie form. The acting is one of the worst you can expect, but, in a good, funny way. Same goes for the jokes that are so bad that they end up being quite funny due the excessive amount of randomness they represent.

Your weapon can be two: Either your own Keyboard, where typing is key as you need to write as fast as possible to engage in combos, avoid damage and score even more points or your mouse to point and shoot. What you type, however is up to you. Whether you are playing the base or not there’s a lot to choose from when it comes to the vocabulary. There are 5 DLCs (I own 4 of them) which can focus more on a certain theme when it comes to what you type. While I found it funny it was a challenge for me since not only I found out I’m incredible slow at typing but also, English is not my native language. I feel this game can improve your typing skills but when it comes to improve your language I’m not so sure. Unless you are interested in the most random sort of things to call at someone.

Visuals are decent enough. They are not modern visuals by any means but this game should not be played for its visuals either way. The sound however, felt a bit of a letdown. Every time I had to use some sort of QTE to kill a bigger enemy (in both modes) the sound/music would go lower and some narration as well other sound effects would get completely silenced for a short period of time. I don’t know if the Developers are aware of this or if they intend to solve this issue.

Aside of the two different modes you can play there are also 3 Mini-games: “Victim Support”, “Stayin’ Alive” and “Money Shot II”. These can be fun as something to play between longer/deep games in order to fill those dead times. Finally, there is also Collectibles in this game. You can collect from Comic Book pages to Soundtracks to play in your Jukebox, Concept Art and also 3D Models from the characters and enemies. As in mostly games, they are completely optional. In the end, I had a pleasant time with this game and I would recommend it for the reasons I wrote above. The duo of bad horror and comedy are mixed well enough to keep you entertained for some time.

reviewText:
This game is perfect if you enjoy typing (and are decent at it), and if you like a cheesy, low-budget horror movie style. The look and story are a parody on exploitation kind of movies, with lots of vulgar and violent themes. Two agents team up to make their way through all kinds of places like buildings, sewers, a stripclub, and even a swamp. On their way to find the great evil crime lord 'Papa Caesar', they shoot (or I should say type) their way through hordes of zombies Mutants to get to their goal.

The typing elements in this game are really good, if you're familiar with the basics of blind typing then you're good to go. It's even more fun if you're a fast typer, you can challenge yourself on the hardest difficulty, and turn on the 'Hardcore'-option, to make no mistakes. After you've finished a level, you can view your typing stats. It's truly enjoyable if you like typing. You might even improve your skills a little bit.

While this is a reboot in the series of The House of the Dead, don't expect it to be like the old games on the Dreamcast. It's got a completely new charm. The game has a decent amount of stuff to offer. It's a good port of the original game with lots of content and minigames. In every level there are collectables to get, which vary from viewable 3D-models to Audio tracks. The game also comes with the original 'The House of the Dead: Overkill', which is essentially the same game with mouse/controller option, but with weapon upgrades. It's fun to replay a level on a harder difficulty to challenge yourself, so the replayability is decent as well.

Typing was never this hilarious before. With an over the top story and lots of swearing, violence and vulgarity, this game offers a fun and unique way to see how good you are at typing and to enjoy an on-rail shooter. If you like typing and zombies, then I can recommend this.

reviewText:
This is when all the right type meets video games. Your keyboard is your weapon.

The typing of the dead is about typing fast, and firing off as many shots as you can as quickly as you can with each letter you type. This game could only appeal to those gamer's who for whatever reason, like typing as quick as they can or like practicing their typing skills.

The story mode does it's best to go as ludicrous as possible. Two of our main characters are lunatic gunmen who love their dialogue. It's entertaining, while some may find it tacky or simply corny. One of the first things I noticed in this game mode is that zombies were missing half their body at times (check screen shots). The word that you needed to type would be there, but only the zombies head or maybe arms were present. So in this regard, game-play will not be affected (only your eyes)! There are different modes in the game such as mini-games, multiplayer, and even an overkill mode. Without these different modes, I'm sure the game would get old... very fast. What bugs me to an extreme extent is the game ignores commas and spaces. I tried the easiest to the hardest difficulty and in no way does that matter for punctuation, spaces, or dashes. I would say for a typing game, you can't simply ignore punctuation if you are going to include it in the game. At the very least, include it in the difficulty.

Even with some zombies missing their torso, I still like the game as it gives me a reason to practice my typing. Some gamer's may find it quickly boring, some may actually like the arcade set style Sega used in this. Graphics overall are respectable and will remind the gamer of playing at an arcade machine. Sounds are okay simply as they do not vary between gun shot sounds and zombies. The voice acting is pretty lucrative and creative though!

One complaint though, I can't change video settings... only brightness. Also, the loading times at certain screens are brutal.


RATING : 6.9/10


Gameplay	B-	Story / Campaign	B-	Visuals / User Interface	C+	Sounds / Music	B-	Replay-ability	C	Overall 	C+

Upon completing the game, I like it. I like the fact your keyboard is your weapon. I do however, have an issue with random words that won't be used. Yes, seeing vulgar words are funny, but I feel the game should strive for actually improving our typing skills through a good game. What they did for the final boss  with the chain gun allowing you to type whatever words you'd like  was a great way to end the game.

reviewText:
To start, I'll answer the question I don't see many reviews covering: Yes, this game can help you improve your typing, assuming you know your fundamentals (homerow concept, finger placement, etc.). I don't see it going over very well if you don't know the basics, but if you do it can be a pretty effective tool, even if it wasn't exactly designed for this purpose.

I wasn't a very good typist when I started. I tested myself online after my first game session and was around 18 wpm with frequent glances at the keyboard. I've treated playing the game like lessons, set periods on a schedule. I usually play 3 chapters a weeknight, which equals about an hour to an hour and a half long sessions.  I started on the lowest difficulty and worked my way up. As I said, this game isn't exactly designed as a teaching tool. If you suck at typing, you die a lot. I was dying as much as a dozen times a stage early on. You'll pretty much have to ignore scoring at this point and just focus on progressing.

It's worth noting that I had a pretty bad handicap early on: I didn't know you could pick up items with tab. I assumed the pickups were only for playing the game the traditional way. They give you a single hint about this early on, but it completely went over my head and didn't give it much more thought. On the plus side, this gave me some pretty raw data for seeing my skills progress, as my score and deaths weren't being affected by collectibles and health.

As I said, I died a lot in the beginning, but by the time I was a few hours in I didn’t have to look at the keyboard anymore. I really started to notice an improvement with my speed when I began the first stage on the hardest difficulty, after completing the easier two. The parts of that stage's boss that had been giving me trouble suddenly weren’t so bad. I think I died once on that attempt, which was far and away a new record. I eventually stalled out toward the end of that play through and decided to scale it back to the medium difficulty for a while. Now I'm trying the hardcore mode on easy to force me to work on accuracy. Seems to be working so far.

It's been three weeks since I started this, 17 hours of play according to steam. I tested myself again at the end of this last session and got 39 WPM (followed by a fist pump). With these results, I don't see myself stopping this routine for a while. Sure beats those mundane online lessons I looked at a while back.

Now, as for the game itself.  It’s pretty fun. You can play the game traditional rail shooter style with the mouse, but I only did a single level so I don’t have a lot of experience on that part. 3 Hours is about one playthrough, and that’s a fair time for something like this. The higher difficulties and Hardcore mode will give you more to do afterward. They’ve also been releasing DLC libraries to expand the pool of words the game will throw at you. They help keep things varied, but I wouldn’t pay more than a dollar or so for them. There are some mini games, but they aren’t anything overly special.

I should also probably mention that this isn’t the highest quality port. It’s nothing really bad, but you may run into some glitchy parts. Specifically, everyone apparently has some sound issues during the “hammertime” kill on the Rage mutants, and one of them always clips into the ground when he runs toward you. I also have had one of the bosses glitch out and stun himself on occasion. Less bothersome, the gallery takes forever to load, to the point you might think it’s stuck.  Besides these and the “invincible zombie” glitch I ran into once, that’s pretty much the worst of it, so nothing to write the purchase off over.

And now for game content.  It’s really, really vulgar. The violent was a given, but I would have been completely blown away by the ridiculous amount of language if I hadn’t read about it before hand. It’s extremely obvious the game is grindhouse and exploitation parody, but that doesn’t stop the obscenities from grating your ears. This game had the Guinness record for the videogame with the most uses of the f-word for a year. Mafia 2 now has that record, but at least that game doesn’t cram the words into a 3 hour period. To answer another question no one seems to tackle, you won’t be typing a lot of obscenities yourself. I’ve typed “Oh ♥♥♥♥!”, ” damned” and “damnation”(offensiveness debatable), “♥♥♥♥♥♥♥”, and “♥♥♥♥♥”, I think. So it’s like 1 in 700 or so. If you want to type vulgarities for some reason look into the “Filth” DLC. As for sexuality and nudity, I’ve seen worse. A couple of characters are strippers, but there’s no nudity in the traditional sense (as for that last boss though… *shutter*).

So, if you want to improve your typing or just kill zombies through the least likely of manners, and you think you can handle the obscene content, give the game a go, I’m glad I did. It sure helped to make typing all this out easier.

reviewText:
Absolutely awesome. It really tests your typing skills while delivering a hilarious story. This is one of the most entertaining games I've played in a long time. It's a short game, broken down into chapters, each chapter with a B horror movie spoof cut scene. The characters are ridiculous and completely over-the-top. It's almost deliberately awful, full of profanity, sexual innuendo, gore, and crazy love affairs. Isaac Washington swears nearly every other word, sometimes multiple words in a row, and while some may be turned off by this, it's one of the comedic highlights of the story and is actually relevant to the relationship building between Washington and Agent G. There are some great quotable lines, but nothing appropriate to display (in case kids are reading).

The gameplay is very simple. Words pop up. You type. There are three difficulty settings. They are introducing new dictionaries as DLC to expand the words that you need to type. Each level has collectibles. A co-op mode is included, but I haven't tried that yet.

You can also play the game with shooting instead of typing, though I found this a little difficult to do with a mouse. The typing mode is more fun anyways. There's a variety of mini-games. They are okay, but I only played each once.

Obviously the graphics are dated since this was a Dreamcast game. I think it still looks fine. The soundtrack is good and fits the game well.

If you're looking for a game you can play in 20 minute increments when you need to pass some time, this is a great choice. That's about how long each level lasts.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lR-3U8eaX7E&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA

The Typing of the Dead:  Overkill is a corny retro arcade-style on the
rail shooter that gives you the option of killing the 'mutants' by either
weapon or death by spelling.  The game is story heavy, and while it is comedic, it has more of an adult theme.

It has an easy interface, and a leaderboard so you can compare yourself
to you friends.  It also has a co-op option, which I feel only adds to the
enjoyment of the game.  Using guns, the game is balanced in its' combat, and the only issue I had was a slight aim difficulty in shooting special items as you bob a lot. In the typing version, the difficulty increases in length of words or number of words.


A skill in spelling is beneficial to progress.  As I stated before, this game does have an mature theme, and I doubt it may help those who wish to improve spelling, as the graphic content of the story and some of the words makes this more appropriate for adults.

Overall, I found this game to be enjoyable;  it does what it set out
to do in a simplistic yet entertaining manner.  It's corny, and I have no
problems recommending this game.

For more details, see the linked video review, as this is a basic
summary of what I cover in my video, I am a YT'er not a Blogger.

Thanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.

http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText: This is really two games in one. You get a PC port of the Director's Cut of The House of the Dead: Overkill and Typing of the Dead: Overkill. The first is a rail shooter, and the second is the same game except that you type instead of clicking to shoot.\n\nThis is, however, a more barebones conversion than you might expect. Unlike the original Typing of the Dead, only the last boss has a gimmick" for what you have to type. No answering questions in this one. In the cutscenes
date: the characters still carry and use guns (not keyboards). Dictionary DLC is available if you want a greater variety of things to type (THANKS OBAMA).\n\nThe multiplayer for Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a nice feature
recommended: but has some odd sync issues and can be frustrating for both players if one is a more proficient typist than the other.\n\nIf you like typing
voteText: and swearing

reviewText:
Do you like really bad grindhouse movies? Do you long for the days of Mario Teaches Typing? If so, you might enjoy The Typing of the Dead: Overkill.

The story is straight up goofy grindhouse style, including the psychadelic Intermission load screens. If you know how to type, this game can be pretty fun. If you hunt and peck to type, this game probably isn't for you. However, there is the option to play the game as The House of the Dead: Overkill" which will allow you to use a controller or mouse to just shoot stuff. I can't really recommend that portion of the game though. It's actually pretty bad.

The game is broken up into fairly short chapters
date: which will allow you to play in quick bursts without having to sit down and spend a lot of time getting into it.\n\nThe game doesn't really offer much new game play as you move along

reviewText:
The first typing of the dead was a useful tool for helping practice fast, accurate typing. In this one, it's just a gimmick. There were about a hundred things they could have done to improve or innovate past that one, yet they instead just looked up the 300 least used words in the English language and slapped them onto a mod for House of the Dead Overkill.

It is also among the few games in history that found a way to charge you for WORDS as downloadable content.

Just get the first Typing of the Dead.

reviewText: The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a violent, brain splattering typing game that has you wielding a keyboard instead of a gun to stop waves of zombies. The light gun games are fun and this is a novel twist, but you really have to be up on your typing to play them. If you find it frustrating when playing a PC game and keyboard quick time events pop up, you won’t be good at this game. You have to be able to type, hit random keys and keep an eye on the screen the whole time. If you played the last one, this one amps up the silly factor with over the top cussing and over the top grindhouse style scenes that contain sex and violence.\n\nCheck out the video review of this title on youtube, in Steam Shots EP125

reviewText:
In this game you play as Mavis Beacon. Only zombies have sprung and you have to adapt your touch typing skills to combat the undead. She also sports double D's and bazookas inorder to kill zombies, using the power of the English language.

In all srsness TotD:O is a sequel to the original Typing of the Dead, only it is based on House of the Dead Overkill. It is a parody of grindhouse movies and regularly makes fun of itself. The main strength of this game is it's humor. Things like the level design, the dialogue, the fact you type out words to kill zombies. It is as ridiculous as the genre it exists in, so take solace in knowing that.

While the game does serve as an effective teaching aid for typing. I wouldn't say it's as good as the original. The nonsensical grindhouse atmosphere doesn't really compare to the gritty PS1 graphics presentation of Totd. It is also less difficult, and for typing veterans it won't exactly be your next Dark Souls. On the flipside the game allows you to switch to a fully functional port of House of the Dead Overkill.

At the very least Typing of the Dead Overkill continues the tradition laid out by it's predecessor by being one of the only educational games that doesn't suck.

reviewText:
Have you ever thought that you could kill hordes of zom­bies just by typ­ing words on your key­board?? No? Well now you have the chance!

Typ­ing of the Dead: Overkill is about to make you improve your typ­ing skills with­out any fuss or wor­ries! Hordes of undead come at you with words high­lighted under­neath them, which you must then type as quickly as pos­si­ble in order to kill them. Each let­ter you type cor­re­sponds to a sin­gle gun­shot, but unfor­tu­nately there are no head­shot here, so you will have to type the whole word or words in order to kill the zombies!

The story of the game does not really have any­thing to offer, how­ever the funny and obscure dia­logues of the char­ac­ters as well as the con­tin­u­ous action will keep you occu­pied for a cou­ple of hours, which is how long this game is….

One might think that typ­ing and mov­ing your char­ac­ter at the same time must be dif­fi­cult, how­ever there is no need to worry. The game moves the char­ac­ters on its own, in a scripted fash­ion, there­fore allow­ing you to con­cen­trate on the mat­ter at hand! Killing them zombies!

The game is sep­a­rated into acts, each one of them con­clud­ing with a boss fight, where things do get trick­ier. Typ­ing words at the cor­rect moment is what does the trick here, plus you’ll have to avoid pro­jec­tiles which will hit you unless you type a spe­cific let­ter very fast. Not too much of a vari­ety, but it’s still fun.

Graph­ics and sound resem­ble a game which has been pro­duced in the last decade (this is a Wii port after all), how­ever the nar­ra­tor does an excel­lent job of push­ing the story for­ward, while the voice overs, even though they lack in finesse, are so funny and insult­ing at times, that it is actu­ally a blast play­ing this game. The sounds from the guns do get repet­i­tive, as most of the time a hand gun is all you have at your dis­posal, and it some­times can­not even be heard as its sound is cov­ered by the voice overs, let­ting you won­der whether you are pulling the trig­ger or not.

This is not a game that will keep you occu­pied for long, and its replaya­bil­ity is ques­tion­able. The only rea­son for you to want to go back is either to improve your high score, or find all the col­lectibles which are scat­tered through­out the act.

With that being said, the Typ­ing of the Dead:Overkill is not a bad game. It is actu­ally a dif­fer­ent and fun game, and it does have its moments. Zom­bie lov­ing gamers should give it a go, as it resem­bles a cult B-movie where you can take part and expe­ri­ence some zom­bie killing which is quite dif­fer­ent from what we’re used to in the cur­rent days.

Read more reviews at: http://www.blowsomesteam.com/the-typing-of-the-dead-overkill/

reviewText:
This game is the only thing that makes me feel alright about being a slow typer. I have become a faster and more accurate typer because of this game. Not only does the game give you Typing of the Dead(based off of the Wii version of HotD:O), but it also gives you House of the Dead: Director's Cut(based off of the PS3 version). Both of the game's modes can be played in singleplayer, or in online multiplayer. There are also 3 mini-games for each of the game's modes, that can be played in singleplayer or online multiplayer. The netcode is great, and is fully playable with people who are 1,000+ kms(621.4+ miles) away.

All the DLC dictionary wordlists can be active at the same time, expanding the total wordpool and adding more variety/replayability. There are also settings for how often you want to see the DLC words being used while playing. The developers have been great with the DLC, so far there have been 3 free DLCs, along with 5 paid DLCs. The free DLCs are of the same quality as the paid DLC, so if you are interested in what the paid DLC is like, then be sure to try the DLC that is already included in your game. *As of July 2014*

NOTE 1: There is no language filter for this game. So parents may not want to use this game as a teaching aid for younger children, unless you are willing to let your children hear a lot of cursing. Personally, I do not have a problem with letting children hear cursing(especially in a game full of gore and killing), but it is definitely a deciding factor for some parents. If you are one of those parents, make sure you are using Steam's Parental Controls to prevent your children from playing this game. The original Typing of the Dead is a great option for these parents(although it is not on Steam).

NOTE 2: Local Multiplayer will not be implemented into the game. While theoretically possible, there is a great challenge in having a PC differentiate between 2 or more keyboards at the same time. While it is not impossible to implement, it was never part of the original plan for the game. So unless you are willing to fund this feature yourself(better get a Kickstarter going as game development is not cheap), do not continue to create topics asking for this feature on the Steam/SEGA forums. The developers are aware of the fan desire for this feature, and are looking into it for future games.

reviewText:
Overkill je treća igra iz ToTD serijala, bazirana na istoimenoj House of The Dead igri sa Playstationa 3. Kao i u prethodnim igrama, horde zombija (pardon, mutanata) ćete slati dva metra pod zemlju kucajući reči i fraze koje se pojavljuju na ekranu. Igra poseduje prebogat rečnik krcat komičnim frazama i citatima tako da se stvaraju brojne urnebesne kombinacije.

Poredeći sa prvom igrom iz serijala, Overkill deluje ‘’mršavije’’, sa jednostavnijim boss fajtovima i samo tri mini igre bez specijalnih vežbi slepog kucanja. Veliki plus igra dobija i na bonusu u vidu opcije igranja originalnog House of the Dead: Overkill sa dodatnim poglavljima i sadržajem.

Definitivno naslov koji morate igrati kao party igru u društvu ljubitelja trash i zombi filmova!

reviewText:
I remember playing House of the Dead: Overkill on my Nintendo Wii whilst friends gather to watch at Hendrix College. I usually...okay...RARELY go for this sort of low brow humour, but I find the story absolutely funny as s****! Of course, I mainly got the game cause I was looking for a good arcade shooter, which it didn't disappoint.

Fastforward to graduation and three years later, I heard about Typing of the Dead, a port to the pc of House of the Dead 2. I wonder if Overkill had gotten the same treatment. To my delight, it had. You shall be laughing your rear off with the words that appear on the screen; yet at the same time you will have aderaline pumping to type as fast and as accurate as you can.

If you want to practice your touch typing skills, this game is perfect for it! Also, it has both a UK and US option as far as dictionary!! Woot! I no longer have to overcorrect myself because a certain country spells armour" as "armor"."

reviewText:
Back in years long past, when I was a wee lad, schools sought fit to have an entire class devoted to developing proper typing skills and technique. Maybe they still do? Why would I know? I don't hang around schools, that would be weird.

Anyway, we would naturally rush through our assignments to play games like Chip's Challenge on those silly lab computers. This game reminded me of that time and what could have been. Perhaps you remove the grindhouse context from the game and put something nice and PG there, and man that would've been an entire class.

As I'm a grown up, I prefer the grindhouse aspect. Here it's particularly well done, being simultaneously cheesy but delightful in a semblance of originality that permeates the game from the gameplay itself to the presentation. You wouldn't think you could come up with boss battles with a setup like this, but I'd be damned if it didn't happen.

reviewText:
DISCLAIMER:I have never taken any other typing courses, so I can't tell whether it's objectively any good at that.
I don't know whether the words chosen in the game make sure that you learn to use your entire keyboard,
but it does seem to be that way, also English is not my native language so if sentences don't make any sense, sorry...

Positives:The game forces you to look at the screen when typing, so you can be better at typing blindly.
The levels are all around 10-15 minutes, so you can choose when you want to stop.
You can get extra points for typing precisely and quickly.
You can use custom word dictionary's if you like (you can download them from the workshop.)
The game is generally constantly changing so you need to be paying close attention
This game is a great way to learn to type on your new mechanical keyboard (I had a hard time with that in the beginnning.)
Negatives:There is no way to continue the level halfway through when you die.
The game is NSFW (but you probably expected that, I don't care anyway, you might)
On my computer a lot of textures refuse to load completely, this is a common problem, but a quick google search reveals the issue can be fixed easily. (There appear to be no problems on Nvidia cards though...)
There are barely any graphics options (just AA)
The cutscenes are BAD, like, REALLY BAD, luckily you can skip them and not miss out on anything.
Conclusion:The game is really fun as a typing course, but beyond that, there is not really anything else.
If you just want to buy this game because: zombies; then don't, you'll get bored really quick and you're wasting your money.
There is no way to recommend this game as anything other than a typing course, and I recommend it as exactly that.
If you are allready good at typing (unlike me), you can still have a lot of fun, my buddy did that and he had a great time.
So in concusion: This game is great (I think) as a typing course but not really as anything else.

reviewText:
As someone who came to the Dreamcast fairly late in its lifecycle, I mostly missed out on the original Typing of the Dead. What few run-ins I had with the game were care of friends whom I didn't see terribly often, and stock of the Dreamcast keyboard dried up before I could afford to track one down. At least we still had arcades around the same time, and I had fed plenty of quarters into many a House of the Dead cabinet up to that point.

When House of the Dead: Overkill came along, I got a chuckle out of the idea of an over-the-top successor to the series, but it didn't really grab my attention. But add typing into the mix, giving me the chance to make up for missing the original? Sold.

The updates from House of the Dead's general goofiness to an even more ridiculous grindhouse motif, complete with the latter's ridiculous gore and doubling down on vulgarity, somehow make sense in a game whose predecessors were known for monster outbreaks for no good reason in an inexplicable location. And things are so off-the-wall already that working the typewriters into things makes just as much sense. Unfortunately, unlike the original Typing of the Dead, the use of a keyboard as a weapon isn't as integrated into Overkill's story or cutscenees. Characters still wave around the same guns they use in the regular gameplay, rather than sporting backpacks with keyboards looped in front of their bodies as per the original. A mild difference, and one that would've made many of the action-loaded cutscenes even more difficult to pull off had they stuck with it.

That aside, the game is fantastic. The vocabulary necessary to progress ramps up at a perfect pace, though it feels like it plateaus a few levels too early. Boss fights and some of the segues between sections are creative, and keep mixing things up as much as you can for what's basically Mavis Beacon Goes Through Hell. It's also nice that there are several DLC packs available with new lexicons, should you find a certain vernacular more familiar and therefore a bit easier to keep up with. The little bonuses you get for snagging collectables in each level are cute, too.

It's a bit gross in some respects, but that's part of the whole grindhouse aesthetic. If you're not into that, you're not going to be into this, but otherwise? Have a good time.

reviewText:
A really inferior port of what looks to have been an excellent game otherwise. There are an incredible amount of graphical and audio glitches, such as music cutting out and not repeating; characters' lines cutting out mid-sentence or just not saying them altogether; preset animations clipping through the environment or through characters; etc.

Plus, a lot of depth from the original game has been stripped; there are no different weapons, and bosses no longer really require skill other than typing speed. I was left feeling like I had missed a lot of interesting gameplay elements from the original game.

Plus, as to be expected, playing the actual House of the Dead game rather than the Typing of the Dead version is completely worthless. It has all the depth that was stripped out of Typing of the Dead, but since it's controlled with your mouse rather than a light gun, it becomes sluggish and unfun to play.

A good game in concept, especially considering the popularity of the original Typing of the Dead, but the poor optimization and lazy stripping of depth really kills what could have made this game a worthy sequel.

reviewText: The sequel to the original Typing of the Dead, TotD: Overkill is a batshit crazy typing tutor wrapped in deliberately terrible voice acting and grindhouse cinema tropes. Words pop up on screen, you type them out, and completing sentences kills zombies. Things are mixed up a bit with boss fights, minigames, flying cutlery, and an internal dictionary that is beyond deranged. Add to that they throw in regular House of the Dead: Overkill for free (essentially the same game, swapping typing for clicking and shooting) and a host of difficulty settings and modes makes it well worth the £14.99 price tag.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Not only do you still have the same hilariously fun light-gun game from the PS3 but you also the typing mode is incredibly fun and challenging, now before you walk into it there is a few things to keep in mind, this is NOT a serious game and this is NOT a game that's trying to 'wow' it's audience with phenomenal visuals, in fact it's going the opposite direction on purpose.

The visuals and sound the game doesn't have much to write home about, the soundtrack and dialogues are fantastic in a cheesy way and they don't skimp on the cheese. The entire game has a gridnhouse, Z movie, vibe to it with a story that's intentionally stupid, chockfull of F-bombs with exagerated gore and hilariously ridiculous plot twists.

There is a good ammount of replay value as well, playing the Typing mode on the Agent(normal) difficulty already proves a challenge and gradually stepping it up to the Motherf**ker (Hard) difficulty with hardcore mode turned on is a whole other challenge altogether. I haven't tried the DLC dictionaries but they should also add a new layer of difficulty to an already challenging game.

If there are a comple of downsides. One, is that the bosses often have a very unforgiving timing to counter their attacks or that the final boss just didn't feel very well polished. Two, is that the leaderboards are often hacked, so even if you'd like to try to make it to the top-scores the hackers just ruin it for everyone.

To sum it up, like it's predecessor, it's still an unique game, I've yet to see any other games to take this aproach to on-rails shooters and it still is a very fun experience, no mention that playing enough of this game might even improve your 'motherf**king' typing skills.

reviewText:
Mavis Beacon is back...and she's hungry for your BLOOD.

Probably the most foul-mouthed way to improve at a valuable and career-applicable skill.  The humor mostly falls into the trying-too-hard-to-be-grindhouse-while-missing-the-point category, but it's still entertaining.

The typing gameplay actually improves the light gun gameplay - because you're not only practicing something useful, but the gameplay actually lets you strategize about which targets to attack or when to start typing what.  Suprisng amount of depth in threat-management.

The only *real* downside to all this is the lack of goofy dreamcasts and keyboards strapped to the player characters a-la the original typing of the dead.

Definitely get this.  In my opinion, all future 'house of the dead' games should have a typing mode - maybe even let you play light gun along side a typist or whatever.

Oh and the added multiplayer mode they patched in is great.  For ♥♥♥♥s sake, why haven't you bought this game already?

reviewText:
The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a welcome addition to the ever-so neglected type 'em up genre that the original Typing of the Dead pioneered. Much like the original, this game is a re-working of the original release of House of the Dead: Overkill which replaces aiming cursors to deal with foes with typing strings of words to dispatch them instead. The feeling of typing often-hilarious combinations of words and phrases to lay waste to everything on screen is still a very satisfying feeling, but not-so-great typists may want to be wary that the difficulty curve isn't quite as gentle as the original Typing of the Dead. Overkill is much less a learning to type aid and definitely more for those of us that are a bit more competent with the keyboard.

This game also includes the extended cut of House of the Dead: Overkill, which can be played as an on-rails shooter with a gamepad or mouse. Though this is the way the game was originally released, it's fairly bland compared to the Typing of the Dead version, and in no way holds up to any of the previous House of the Dead games. Enemy variety is sparse, the combo-driven scoring system is a chore to manage, boss fights have almost no creativity or gimmicks worth noting, and the weapon upgrade system never really feels all that significant. It's nice that this version of the game comes included as opposed to being sold as DLC, but the overall ho-hum presentation and lack of variety really makes clicking through hordes of mutants an exercise in tedium as opposed to a fun arcadey experience.

Typing of the Dead: Overkill is definitely a game worth checking out, but maybe not at full price. Trail-blazing a path of carnage through seemingly endless hordes of mutants with just your keyboard is definitely exciting, but the lack of any real variety and the ham-fisted grindhouse trappings wear thin only a few stages in and you may be done with the game long before it's done with you.

reviewText:
Pro
Hilarious dictionary
UK and US English supported
Original House of the Dead: Overkill included
Con
If you didn't like House of the Dead: Overkill - you'll have a hard time with this.
At the moment, many Steam users are having trouble running the game
Probably painful to play if you can't touch type
Some may be familiar with the rail shooter House of the Dead: Overkill. Made to look like a series of 1970s exploitation splatter horror films, the game is full of bad language, sexual references, blood, guts, vomit and general gross stuff. It would be just as offensive to some people as it would be funny to others. Typing of the Dead: Overkill is the same game but with the gun cross-hairs and control mechanism taken away and replaced with a typing interface. When a mutant shows up, a word or phrase appears below which you are supposed to type out correctly. Each key-press rings out with a gunshot which, when you are touch typing, is really satisfying. As someone who is quite poor at shooters but pretty good at typing it's a nice change, though, I can imagine that non-touch typers may find the game extremely frustrating.

The typing mechanic obviously changes the dynamic of the original game. To some degree it puts the shooter on even tighter rails, if that's a correct way to put it. House of the Dead, like other rail shooters, has extra stuff that you can shoot all over the place - in the transition to Typing of the Dead, it would not have made sense to add text tags to everything on-screen or it would have been extremely cluttered. Since only immediate threats are (usually) tagged it makes for a more focused experience.

What makes Tying of the Dead, though, is the dictionary used. At the very start when the easy targets start to swarm, you get simple but relevant words thrown out. Things like, 'dead', 'blood', 'gore' and such. But as soon as the first heavy trots out? 'Onomatopoeia'! Of course when the phrases start showing up and they say things like Do a barrel roll" you get an idea of what you'll see throughout the course of the game. Mercifully
date: you can set the dictionary to UK or US English which I'm sure everyone can agree is important.\n\nAs a bonus
recommended: the original House of the Dead: Overkill game is included though I found it a bit clunky to play after having total keyboard accuracy.\n\nProbably the most frustrating thing about the Steam edition is that
voteText: there seems to be a common problem with the game crashing quickly after launching or failing to launch at all. If you look through the forum posts you can find some advice but it seems to be a graphics issue which some have resolved by either running the game in XP compatibility mode
helpfulPercent: installing the latest GPU drivers
votesHelpful: or running the game in windowed mode. I got it to run by using windowed mode which is a drag.\n\nI must confess I was not a huge fan of the House of the Dead: Overkill. It's probably too gross for my sensibilities and the humour of the story seemed to me to try a bit to hard. However its conversion into Typing of the Dead: Overkill
votesTotal: an adults only typing game provided unexpected enjoyment."

reviewText:
Typing of The Dead Overkill (TOTD) is an HD remake of House of the Dead 2 (HOTD2), an arcade “rail shooter.”  I never played the original (which came out over 15 years ago) so I can’t tell you how closely it follows the original story. I can’t imagine it’s too closely though since Typing of the Dead Overkill is filled with profanity/nudity.

The original HOTD2 was a basic rail shooter where you have no control of movement, you just point and click at any zombies that pop up on the screen. TOTD is similar, except that instead of using the mouse to point and click, a random word will pop up on the screen over an enemy's head and you need to type it into the keyboard as fast as you can (otherwise the zombie will bite you). For example, you’re moving down the hall and two zombies shamble into view from one of the doors. Above each zombie’s head is a word, such as KILL or DEATH. If you type the word in correctly, the zombie gets “shot” and dies. If the zombie runs in from far away you might have to type in a longer word, and if an enemy throws a knife at you, you might just have to hit one key to deflect it. It can get pretty hairy when half a dozen zombies crawl out and you need to pick which word to type first (kill the closest zombie first!) Each level has a boss at the end, often with some special way to kill them.

Storywise, every level has a prologue and epilogue along with a bunch of wisecracks during the missions. You play one of 2 cops who are chasing a madman who released a zombie virus. On alternating levels, you play one of 2 strippers who are also chasing the same bad guy. By the way, like the arcade the game is made for 2 players, though I haven’t tried multi-player. The environments are varied and so are the enemies, but the variety is really just for visuals since you kill everyone the same way (type the word over their head).

In addition to the TOTD campaign, the original HOTD2 game is included with updated graphics. It’s basically the exact same game except you use the mouse to point and shoot enemies. Using the mouse is actually a lot harder since you actually need to aim at some smaller enemies (evil crows!) and shoot bosses in their weak spots.

Pros:
+Learn to type random words fast like your life (points) depend on it!
+An over the top story that would never fly in a movie, unless it was a Grindhouse film. Can be funny at times.
+House of the Dead 2 included. (Point and click version of the game).
+Scary and gruesome at times. We’re talking zombies and monsters after all.

Cons:
-Kind of short, maybe 5-6 hours.
-The point & click version can be VERY hard. You have to aim at the knives that get thrown at you or the mutant babies charging at you. I played through easy mode and couldn’t get through a level without being hit.

You might think that with all the typing you’d be a typing expert by the end of the game, but alas I still have to look at my hands when I type some of the words. This might be because you’re only typing in random words instead of complete sentences.  Overall I’m glad I bought the game (Humble Bundle BTA) and would recommend it to anyone who likes rail shooters or zombie games.

reviewText:
I actually really love this game, which is surprising because I'm not a big fan of zombie themed games or movies. I find them really repetitive and they're just the same thing over and over. However, with Typing of the Dead, there are different mechanics that I'm not used to using, like the whole keyboard for example. Even though the plot of the game is pretty thin, it doesn't take itself seriously, and it's pretty entertaining.  I like that it challenges me to type as fast as I can, and there are so many different dictionaries to download, which makes the phrases vary even more than they already do. My only real complaint about this game is that a lot of the achievements are really grindy. You have to play the same levels over and over again, which can get tedious when you marathon games like I do. I've played this game for 8 hours over the past 3 days, so I'm kind of sick of playin the same levels over and over. Even the thrill of getting another achievement has started wearing off. I'll just have to come back to it later to finish it off.

Basically, it's an awesome, fun game, and it'll challenge your skills when it comes to touch-typing. It gets repetitive, but as long as you don't marathon it like I did, it should be okay. It's definitely worth buying if you want to improve your typing skills and/or if you like zombie games.

reviewText:
The idea seemed great but unfortunately this game isn't.

TotD:O feels buggy/unfinished. Sometimes videos won't show (I'll get audio but no visual feedback), the cursor will never show in pre-game menus, the same menus won't allow me to use my keyboard. (weren't we in a typing game?)

It's aesthetic is as uninspired as it gets, and graphics are pretty bad for a 2013 game.

Unfortunately, it doesn't shine as a typing game to make up for that.
While it seems to be competently unforgiving of typing errors (you'll almost always get hit in return), it is plagued by questionable decisions: the games ignores all spaces, doesn't differentiate between upper and lower case, and won't make you remove typing error with backspace before letting you continue, making the gameplay a spam and pray one.
On top of that, the game doesn't give you intuitive feedback on threat priorities, forcing you into fail and retry for some scenes. (civilians to save, boss fights)

This brings me to another characteristic of the game: it is a railroad shooter, you'll always get the exact same experience (same dialogs and same camera movements), and I was already sick of it 2 minutes into restarting the first level.

You may consider the writing and humor of the game to be a redeeming factor, but it is hit or miss at best.
As you may surmise, it was a huge miss with me, getting only one genuine laugh out of me in what was otherwise an ocean of bad jokes in a generic z-movie zom... mutant plot.

TL;DR: probably not worth the $20 price tag. Get your hand on a demo to double-check if the game fits your tastes and isn't buggy on your computer before buying.

reviewText:
I...I really do not even know where to begin.  I often had fun, and often wanted to quit playing.  I guess it is good that being faster does not automatically make you better at the game; you lose your combo multiplier if you make two typos in a row, which is a virtual guarantee when you are hitting keys virtually simultaneously and it misses a keystroke.  But then again...the score is completely meaningless.

Every good or bad thing you can think of about the game can be quickly balanced by a similar opposing point.  Incredibly terrible characterization, but obviously intentionally so...completely stereotypically British dialogue said by overwrought American archetypes...but surely that just makes it all the more fun?  Or does it just make it feel like nobody was actually paying any attention to the design of this game the whole time?

One thing you cannot take away from this game: it is the best psychobilly horror typing tutor ever.

reviewText:
The original Typing of the Dead is one of my favorite games of all time. Somehow, this one misses the mark in two important ways.

1. The cutscenes in the original TOTD weren't supposed to be funny. Overkill clearly is, but the contrast between the allegedly serious (if badly executed) House of the Dead 2 and killing them with keyboards is funnier than when the game is already trying to be funny.

2. Far more crucially, in the original TOTD, the words were completely random. In Overkill, the words seem to be joing about the circumstances. Early playthroughs of the first level would give lots of words about horror movies. The boss characters  even less random. I failed against a mutated cheerleader boss. Starting the battle again, I was getting the same words, all cracks at the mutant cheerleader's weight. I personally think the massive library of phrases the original would dispense randomly was far funnier and less boring to play.

These probably sound like nitpicks, but they sapped my enjoyment of the game. I'm sure I'll go back to it someday and play it to completion, because I love typing games. But I can't really recommend it.

reviewText:
I loved the old Typing of the Dead, so I was hugely excited when this game was announced. It peaked at No.2 or No.3 on my wishlist ... and so I was even more disappointed by the game's end result.

Origins
This game is basically the spiritual successor to The Typing of the Dead, which was a modification of the original House of the Dead such that you killed by typing words rather than shooting a laser gun. (How cool is that!)

In this case, the original source material is House of the Dead: Overkill, which received relatively positive reviews years ago, in part due to its stylistic integration of cheesy B-movie film genre and the House of the Dead game franchise.

Story, characters, etc
I don't think anyone plays any House of the Dead games for the plot or characters or anything, but still. The execution couldn't even rate as a neutral factor here, sadly.

I don't think I've ever actually watched a cheesy B-movie film before, and so the style and humor was amusing ... at first. If there were ever an example of beating a dead horse, this game is full of it. Excessive cussing. Lame dialogue. Annoying characters. And voices that make your ears bleed. By the end, all the long cut scenes were a real chore to get through. The cut scenes are skippable, but I generally prefer to watch everything through the first (and in this case final) time.

Game play
As each zombie approaches you, an associated word box will pop up onto the screen. If the zombies are close enough to strike you, the word box will flash. Pretty straightforward. To kill the zombies, you must type the shown word or phrase.

My one complaint is that there are times when there are multiple zombies approaching, and it can be difficult to figure out which word box represents the closer zombie, which can result in unnecessary hits.

If you want to switch to another word box or zombie, I think there's a button that will cancel your progress in the present word box that is faster than just backspacing and typing the other phrase, but I can't remember it off the top of my head.

There are special power-ups, health replenishment or collectibles throughout. If you see them on the screen, hit Tab and they will be automatically collected.

Collectibles
I'm not an achievements ♥♥♥♥♥, but collecting things in this game is so easy because of the linear nature of the game that there's no point NOT making the effort. But the layout to view your collectibles is so horrible. There's no grid ... you literally have to cycle through everything, one by one, and then you have to click on it to see what it actually is. Hugely inefficient.

Replayability
The mini games are a complete waste of time. I can't see anyone enjoying them enough to play them. Only completionists would bother.

This might be more fun to play in multiplayer, but just getting through the single player campaign completely wiped me to the point where I had zero interest in playing this again.

Adding theoretical value is the inclusion of the original House of the Dead: Overkill. However, I didn't play it, so I couldn't tell you whether it's any good.

Overall rating: 5/10. It was fun at first, garnering maybe a 7/10 ... but a few levels in, everything is so repetitive and annoying that the game ends up being quite the unpleasant experience overall.

reviewText:
I've played through the first 3 House of the Dead games in arcade, dreamcast (when available), and Wii. I also owned and played through overkill on wii. I've played the first two typing of the dead games as well.

The original House of the Dead series had lovably bad dialog, but it was in a terribly voice acted way - not just crappily written trying to be funny 'grindhouse' sexist trash kind of plot way. In the overkill spinoffs, the constant misogyny almost overwhelms the bad puns (which I'd normally enjoy.) This game feels distinctly american while the original house of the dead games felt very 'sega', if that makes sense.

But in addition to dated graphics (we're talking about a wii game here, you know) there's a ton of issues like things popping in (and models outright being seethrough, resulting in legs and arms without the rest of the zombie) and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ continuity (a character has their glasses dramatically smacked off only to have them on their face in the next shot). It's pretty sloppy.

Anyway, that being said this is the only typing to kill zombies game on steam and it scratches an itch I've had since the first typing of the dead came out. There's nothing quite like it and I'll probably play it all the way through and go back again at times. The typing part is well done, solid mechanics. Overall the game is pretty fun, if you can ignore the infantile plot and design. So, I suppose, thumbs up on this review.

It also includes the 'normal' version of the game but frankly it's in no way worth playing without a lightgun - mouse or controller just don't cut it.

reviewText:
Very funny in game speech.  This game does not take itself too seriously and is a lot of fun.

Some video bugs - sometimes I get attacked by zombies that are invisible except for their clothes, but you are mainly watching for the target words more than the facial features of the zombie anyway so no biggie.

In the typing mode, often there are lulls with the cut scene video where in a FPS you would be filling the enemy with hot lead, instead you have to wait until the next scene starts with the target words appearing.

The extra dictionaries (e.g. movie names/characters etc.) really notch up the difficulty as you have to type up words that you don't normally type - and fast if you don't want to get your face eaten by a zombie hehe.

All in all, several hours of fun at least, and definately worth showing to friends for a laugh.

reviewText:
This game is a delight to play! I would highly reccommend it especially since it is not just Typing of the Dead but also House of the Dead Overkill Directors Cut, and for £15.00 that is a steal! For those interested I will run down some aspects I liked and didn't like.

Pros
Difficulties aren't just determined by how long the word is but uses genuinely complicated words.
Very vulgar and offensive, some would say sometimes it goes abit far but personally I wasn't too phased by this.
Two Games in one!
Grindhouse feel, from the voiceover to the levels put across as movies this is incredibly entertaining in my view.
Steam Workshop support.
Rankings are used, not much of a selling point for some but it is always fun trying to go back and get a perfect score to achieve S ranking.
The Online Co-op is now fully functional! Abit of healthy competition between friends never goes a miss.
The game has a relatively good sense of humor in my opinion.
Cons
The story is all over the place and very bare bones.
The Typing of the Dead game just isn't the same without Lightguns/ Wii Remote/ Move Controller.
Unlike the original Typing of the Dead, G and Washington use guns rather than keyboards (not a huge problem but abit disappointing)
The game doesn't care about spaces or punctatuation. (outside of the Pro variant that is only unlocked after completion)
The DLC dictionaries don't really stick to the difficulty you have set, it will put words way beyond a newbies skill level even on easy.
Only the House of the Dead Overkill is Directors Cut, for whatever reason Typing is just the base game we saw released on Wii in 2009.
Graphics aren't much to look at.
Sometimes when skipping cutscenes there is mild freezing that will stop in a few seconds but is relatively irratating none the less.
So considering the numerous cons I have toward the game why am I recommending the game? Because it is fun, granted it isn't a technical masterpeice and it's graphics don't even surpass those of previous House of the Dead Games (3 onwards) but it is enjoyable to play and in the end it can even be educational. (If only to an extent due to the vulgarity!)
I would say, if the list of cons has really put you off the game then wait until it is on a deep discount.

reviewText:
I am a terrible typist! My CPM is revolting! I mistype frequently which is shameful! I'm having a ♥♥♥♥ing BLAST, I tell ya!

I do actually feel like I'm improving a bit with this game. Learning to type is not why you play Typing of the Dead though.
You play it because the concept is just so stupid. You play it because a rail shooter where you type at enemies can be unaccountably fun and also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥: Seriously tense sometimes! No horror game has ever raised my heart rate to the degree a silly typing game did at points.

YOU HURT ZOMBIES WITH WORDS. YOU HURT THEIR FEELINGS RIGHT OUT OF THEIR FACES. FEELING LOOKS LIKE BLOOD AND BITS OF FACE

As a bonus you get the original shooty version of the game! It's okay, but obviously not the main event here.

Sometimes the story and presentation does get a bit too close for comfort to the grindhouse movies it parodies. This means the game is really not PC and that can understandably bother some, so be warned.

Some graphics bugs can also happen, which is to do with AMD Radeon drivers I think.

Get this for a laugh when it's on sale, why the hell not?

reviewText:
Bad voice acting, bad animations, questionable graphics, hideous writing and an absolute zero regard for emotional sensitivities.

It's a masterpiece.

If you consider yourself a fast typer or are just looking to brush up on your touch typing, between Mavis Beacon, Mario Teaches Typing and this, you can't go wrong with a little zom- mutant slaughter with big chesticles bouncing around and the jankiest voice acting since the mid 90s.

It's surprisingly satisfying getting a huge score and a nice accuracy rate in a game in which you type words. You'll likely have a chuckle or two at the words and phrases you type, usually relating to the situation you're in or sometimes due to the random dictionary getting a humourous set of words in a sequence.

That said, it's nothing to go rush out for. I picked this up in a sale and I enjoy it a lot but I'd probably pass at the recommended price. I like zombie games and I like typing but I'm pretty stingy.

For an added bonus, you can also play all the chapters of the game in old-school point'n'click shooting mode too - but the charm is lost without a light gun.

reviewText:
I am a terrible typist! My CPM is revolting! I mistype frequently which is shameful! I'm having a ♥♥♥♥ing BLAST, I tell ya!

I do actually feel like I'm improving a bit with this game. Learning to type is not why you play Typing of the Dead though.
You play it because the concept is just so stupid. You play it because a rail shooter where you type at enemies can be unaccountably fun and also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥: Seriously tense sometimes! No horror game has ever raised my heart rate to the degree a silly typing game did at points.

YOU HURT ZOMBIES WITH WORDS. YOU HURT THEIR FEELINGS RIGHT OUT OF THEIR FACES. FEELING LOOKS LIKE BLOOD AND BITS OF FACE

As a bonus you get the original shooty version of the game! It's okay, but obviously not the main event here.

Sometimes the story and presentation does get a bit too close for comfort to the grindhouse movies it parodies. This means the game is really not PC and that can understandably bother some, so be warned.

Some graphics bugs can also happen, which is to do with AMD Radeon drivers I think.

Get this for a laugh when it's on sale, why the hell not?

reviewText:
What is with the acting?  And the horrible graphics?  AND I HAVE TO TYPE?!  I JUST WANT TO SHOOT THINGS!  Come on, people!  A zombie game where I'm not allowed to call them zombies?!  What kind of fresh hell is this?  And, I'm sorry, is it possible to have women in video games who are decently covered and without massive, gravity-defying perky boobs?  I just don't get it.  There are so many things that could have been done right in this game that are done wrong.

And don't get me started on Issac Washington, who can't complete a sentence without cursing.  It's despicable.

This game is great if you like any of the above things.  Also, it's campy as hell.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
House of the Dead Overkill, the black sheep of the series. Terrible writing and story, makes you think that Sega took a break from working on the story from the others and decided to let a group of junior high students write it...

...and I hate to say it but... I love it...

Now compared to the classic House of the Dead 2, Overkill is gutter trash. However it still lives up to House of the Dead goodness. There is two ways to play, as you guessed by the title of it on the store page. Type to kill, or play it the same way the PC House of the Dead's played. The typing game mode is simple enough, you type each word that comes up on screen and move on to the next. It's the norm gamemode (that being normal house of the dead, aim, shoot, kill) that the fun lies. Both are enjoyable, but at best, you really just want to play it the way it was meant to be played. Despite that, the typing is nice when you want to take a break from aiming, it also doubles as typing practice for those who arent the fastest typers.

Score: 8/10 - It's House of the Dead on the PC, nothing more, nothing less. With two ways to play, so think two games in one. Best to get it on sale, however the full price wouldnt be bad to pay either.

Replay Value: High - Each stage has collectibles to obtain, and its always nice to tackle a completed stage with a different weapon. The collectibles, different difficulties, two ways to play, and small but satisfying choice of weapons. A good time killer, and it's always nice going for a higher score than your previous best.

reviewText:
This is a difficult game to recommend.

The game mechanics are great fun, and there's a level of non-typing skill required to make sure that you tackle the zombies mutants in the correct order, or abort your current word to stop a projectile.

Not being a fan of grindhouse, however, it was a difficult game to tolerate. The stereotypes are pushed so hard, and cursing so overdone, that it's almost embarrassing to watch. I can't really comment on the visuals during the game - you'll be so busy typing that you barely notice.

If you've played the original Typing of the Dead, this is a bit of a step backwards in some ways. While it's possibly a bit more polished, the original included more variation in gameplay and several additional minigames and training exercises that are obviously missing here. The mini-games included in this release feel like an afterthought.

reviewText:
Very funny in game speech.  This game does not take itself too seriously and is a lot of fun.

Some video bugs - sometimes I get attacked by zombies that are invisible except for their clothes, but you are mainly watching for the target words more than the facial features of the zombie anyway so no biggie.

In the typing mode, often there are lulls with the cut scene video where in a FPS you would be filling the enemy with hot lead, instead you have to wait until the next scene starts with the target words appearing.

The extra dictionaries (e.g. movie names/characters etc.) really notch up the difficulty as you have to type up words that you don't normally type - and fast if you don't want to get your face eaten by a zombie hehe.

All in all, several hours of fun at least, and definately worth showing to friends for a laugh.
