reviewText:
If you want something fresh, something different from your everyday COD-copy shooter, you should check this title out.

The typing mechanics can be intense, there are a variety of levels from a carnival to a swamp, an onslaught of unluckables, various weapon upgrades, multiple difficulty levels, and so forth. The original version of the game is also included, which you can play with the mouse. While not as much fun as typing away mutants, it is fun in its own way and totally makes it worth doing a second or third run through the story.

Thought I would be turned off by all the over-the-top expletives others have complained about, but it never actually bothered me nor distracted me. In fact, I would say some of the narrator dialog is really well-written. Many of the words you need to type not only change depending on the level you are on, but are also either amusingly dark, subtle references (A Rita Hayworth Poster" during a prison level)
date: or cleaver puns.\n\nKeep in mind that this is an arcade shooter. If you can already type fast
recommended: hardcore mode won't be so hardcore
hoursPlayed: ergo won't take long to complete. I would say if you're only interested in the typing mode and beating it just once
voteText: you can see everything in about two hours. Personally
helpfulPercent: I'm planning on unlocking all the achievements and so estimating I will get a good eight to ten fun hours out of this.\n\nIt's worth paying the admission price for such a unique gaming experience."

reviewText:
This game's a hard one to decide whether to recommend it or not and LET ME TELL YOU WHY.
Let's start with the good things. The soundtrack's stupidly great, with some funny songs in the main menu and catchy tunes in levels. The gameplay which consists of just what the title says, is well made and it too, has some funny words and sentences. The cutscenes have their funny parts and it doesn't take itself seriously at all, which is a nice thing to see in a zomb-mutant game. And for some reason it just doesn't get old. You'd think that this simple idea of just typing would get boring after an hour, but for some reason it just doesn't.
Now, on to the bad things about this game. This game feels unpolished, like a beta game of sorts. The most reoccurring bug I've had has to do with the audio. The soundeffects cut out, the dialogue cuts out and the soundtrack cuts out. These fortunatelly don't happen in cutscenes, but they make certain scenes seem really awful as they have no soundeffects. If you type while looking at your keyboard, the soundeffects cutting out can screw you over as you don't hear when you screw a word up.
Also the game is missing a thing that every game should have: a restart button. Oh yes, if you want  or need to restart you have to:quit to main menu, watch a loading screen, select the mission, watch a loading screen, skip a cutscene and watch a loading screen. Also the loading screens take way too long for a game made in 2013. The restarting progress takes roughly 40 seconds, which is unbearable if you plan on playing on hard or hardcore later, as the game isn't easy. It just gets way too frustrating playing on hard if you aren't some sort of master typer.
Overall this game's good if you aren't planning on playing hard.
5/10 if you're planning on playing on hard and 7/10 if you're planning on playing on normal / easy, which rounds up to 6/10 BUT ONLY BUY IT IF IT'S ON SALE

reviewText:
Good but not great

Its a fun niche game with a ridiculous (in a good way) story. Typing out okey dokey doctor jones" while fending of a horde of zombies is a great feeling. However I must compare this to the previous Typing of the dead game.

Much of the uniqueness of the first game are not present here.  The boss fights are poorly suited for typing in this game.  Gone are the sentence drills or answer a question fights of the first game. The boss fights are not much different from the regular zombies of just typing the word(s) before they attack. Another problem I feel with the game is that  it is too easy. Disclaimer: only ran through once on normal mode. Throughout the game the difficulty between levels was not noticable. On the last level I was still getting words that were 5 characters long. Maybe there were some marginally longer sentences to type out but i would not say it was significant increase in difficulty. Compared to the first game
date: the difficulty was very noticable with some zombies having very long words to type out. Also in the first game
recommended: when you die the difficulty changes dynamically. The difficulty in this game is not dynamic compared to the first. The game also has some general buggy-ness. I had to restart once because when I finished typing out a zombies string
hoursPlayed: it disappered yet the zombie was still there rendering it impossible to me to beat him. Also the audio cut out many times when I had to face rage zombies. Probably the biggest knock I have for the game is that I came across  repeated phrases in a single level  (occured multiple times). I have never seen this happen in the previous game but there should be no reason I see the phrase Killing Twins twice in one level.  This too happened with the DLC I bought . I believe the dlc is much much smaller than i expected it to be.\n\nAs many problems the game has
voteText: it just dumb and fun. Not many other games you can type and kill zombies. Buy it when it goes on sale. Or torrent the superior previous one. I highly recommend the latter."

reviewText:
If you want something fresh, something different from your everyday COD-copy shooter, you should check this title out.

The typing mechanics can be intense, there are a variety of levels from a carnival to a swamp, an onslaught of unluckables, various weapon upgrades, multiple difficulty levels, and so forth. The original version of the game is also included, which you can play with the mouse. While not as much fun as typing away mutants, it is fun in its own way and totally makes it worth doing a second or third run through the story.

Thought I would be turned off by all the over-the-top expletives others have complained about, but it never actually bothered me nor distracted me. In fact, I would say some of the narrator dialog is really well-written. Many of the words you need to type not only change depending on the level you are on, but are also either amusingly dark, subtle references (A Rita Hayworth Poster" during a prison level)
date: or cleaver puns.\n\nKeep in mind that this is an arcade shooter. If you can already type fast
recommended: hardcore mode won't be so hardcore
hoursPlayed: ergo won't take long to complete. I would say if you're only interested in the typing mode and beating it just once
voteText: you can see everything in about two hours. Personally
helpfulPercent: I'm planning on unlocking all the achievements and so estimating I will get a good eight to ten fun hours out of this.\n\nIt's worth paying the admission price for such a unique gaming experience."

reviewText:
The most unexpectedly awesome zombie killing game ever.

For a fast touch typist it's a cakewalk playing this on hardcore difficulty, but the real fun comes from the awesome 70's grindhouse style plot and the increasingly bizarre phrases you have to type to kill the zombies.

Type perfectly again and again to rack up massive combos with bonus points.

And if you get sick of typing and want to shoot - you can switch over to mouse or gamepad mode and blast away, house of the dead style!

Best typing tutor ever.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Typing of the Dead is the kind of game that tells you exactly what it is just by looking at the title. The game is half Mavis Beacon and half House of the Dead. Surprisingly, it is a much better fit than you would think. TTotD is a fast paced, extremely violent, WPM test. With that in mind you will be hard pressed to find a more cathartic and rewarding typing test, with each word and phrase asked of you acting as another bullet in the chamber.\nAs fun as it all is though, everything outside of the main mechanic dampens the experience. Typing of the Dead: Overkill does not try to hide what it is, which is a retooling of the Wii version of House of the Dead: Overkill. It is nice that you have the choice of playing House of the dead or the new Typing version with one purchase, but it is evident that the core design was meant for a light gun or Wii remote, and not much was done for this particular spin-off to exist on its own.\nThe story and presentation is stylized to invoke the grindhouse" style of cinema
date: but that ends up being more trouble than its worth. Even when it is being passed off as campy
recommended: bad writing is still bad writing. And gross tasteless ♥♥♥♥
hoursPlayed: doesn't get better with a "grindhouse" label on it either.\nThe core game
voteText: typing to kill enemies and chaining together kills to boost you're score multiplier is a blast. Just don't be surprised if the rest of the game turns you off a little. I recommend it
helpfulPercent: but I don't excuse the game's lack of taste.\n"

reviewText:
So, writing a review about a game that's about typing? Count me in. :)

This game isn't as good as the old Dreamcast one but it sure is enjoyable at small doses. You play as the 2 most out of place characters in the universe (and 2 chicks that are even more out of place) on a storyline that's good/bad enough to be the plot of some B-movie from the 70's.

The gameplay is addictive, although it gets pretty repetitive after some time, the graphics are really dated by nowdays standards, the controls are what you would expect from a title like this and the replayability is pretty high, since all the words are randomized and you can aim for a better rank/score.

I don't think it's worth it's full price if you're not a fan of the franchise since it's a game that you would play only on small dosis, but expect those small dosis to be fun and franctic. But if you are a fan, buy this game now: You probably won't regret it.

If you need a score, I'll give this game a 7/10. It's not as memorable as the first one in the franchise nor it does something different than putting words to type on HOTD: Overkill, but since it comes with it as well, it counts as a good bonus for an already above average game.

reviewText: Probably helps those who are still learning to type faster on the keyboard a lot. Although the excessive swearing and cursing is pretty over the top and gets old really fast. One thing that bothers me the most is that all the available DLCs do is replace the text in the game with quotes from literature and other media. No new enemies. No new levels. Nothing. Just text. And for some reason, each of them costs about $2.99? Please tell me why I should pay $2.99 to enjoy Shakespeare's work in an on-rail zombie typing/shooting game. An appropriate analogy would be having to pay $2.99 to replace the green pipes in Mario with red recolored ones. Completely relevant.\n\nBut other than that, in general it's a very fun game, but not fun enough to justify its pricing. You might wanna wait for a discount offer to get it.

(I am still playing on the easiest level because I'm a chicken. lol) 10/10

reviewText:
The Typing of The Dead: Overkill is the game I wish I had back in grade school. It's crass, vulgar, and at times worthy of more cringe then a fedora. I loved every second I've spent with it.

There is a point-to-shoot version of the game packaged along, but Typing is what really makes this game shine. Between the different DLCs and the standard set of words I was giggling the entire way from start to finish. Don't worry about your typing being slow or not up to par, there's a difficulty mode for everyone. If you're looking to improve your typing skills and words per minute then I can think of no better way then a few afternoons with The Typing of The Dead: Overkill.

That all out of the way, it does fall flat during cooperative play. There is a noticable amount of lag that combined with my partner's finger-pecking typing style led to some very annoying situations. Despite that I maintain that as both an educational tool and as a novelty game Typing of The Dead: Overkill stands proudly above the crowd.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
What is with the acting?  And the horrible graphics?  AND I HAVE TO TYPE?!  I JUST WANT TO SHOOT THINGS!  Come on, people!  A zombie game where I'm not allowed to call them zombies?!  What kind of fresh hell is this?  And, I'm sorry, is it possible to have women in video games who are decently covered and without massive, gravity-defying perky boobs?  I just don't get it.  There are so many things that could have been done right in this game that are done wrong.

And don't get me started on Issac Washington, who can't complete a sentence without cursing.  It's despicable.

This game is great if you like any of the above things.  Also, it's campy as hell.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
House of the Dead Overkill, the black sheep of the series. Terrible writing and story, makes you think that Sega took a break from working on the story from the others and decided to let a group of junior high students write it...

...and I hate to say it but... I love it...

Now compared to the classic House of the Dead 2, Overkill is gutter trash. However it still lives up to House of the Dead goodness. There is two ways to play, as you guessed by the title of it on the store page. Type to kill, or play it the same way the PC House of the Dead's played. The typing game mode is simple enough, you type each word that comes up on screen and move on to the next. It's the norm gamemode (that being normal house of the dead, aim, shoot, kill) that the fun lies. Both are enjoyable, but at best, you really just want to play it the way it was meant to be played. Despite that, the typing is nice when you want to take a break from aiming, it also doubles as typing practice for those who arent the fastest typers.

Score: 8/10 - It's House of the Dead on the PC, nothing more, nothing less. With two ways to play, so think two games in one. Best to get it on sale, however the full price wouldnt be bad to pay either.

Replay Value: High - Each stage has collectibles to obtain, and its always nice to tackle a completed stage with a different weapon. The collectibles, different difficulties, two ways to play, and small but satisfying choice of weapons. A good time killer, and it's always nice going for a higher score than your previous best.

reviewText:
This game is a delight to play! I would highly reccommend it especially since it is not just Typing of the Dead but also House of the Dead Overkill Directors Cut, and for £15.00 that is a steal! For those interested I will run down some aspects I liked and didn't like.

Pros
Difficulties aren't just determined by how long the word is but uses genuinely complicated words.
Very vulgar and offensive, some would say sometimes it goes abit far but personally I wasn't too phased by this.
Two Games in one!
Grindhouse feel, from the voiceover to the levels put across as movies this is incredibly entertaining in my view.
Steam Workshop support.
Rankings are used, not much of a selling point for some but it is always fun trying to go back and get a perfect score to achieve S ranking.
The Online Co-op is now fully functional! Abit of healthy competition between friends never goes a miss.
The game has a relatively good sense of humor in my opinion.
Cons
The story is all over the place and very bare bones.
The Typing of the Dead game just isn't the same without Lightguns/ Wii Remote/ Move Controller.
Unlike the original Typing of the Dead, G and Washington use guns rather than keyboards (not a huge problem but abit disappointing)
The game doesn't care about spaces or punctatuation. (outside of the Pro variant that is only unlocked after completion)
The DLC dictionaries don't really stick to the difficulty you have set, it will put words way beyond a newbies skill level even on easy.
Only the House of the Dead Overkill is Directors Cut, for whatever reason Typing is just the base game we saw released on Wii in 2009.
Graphics aren't much to look at.
Sometimes when skipping cutscenes there is mild freezing that will stop in a few seconds but is relatively irratating none the less.
So considering the numerous cons I have toward the game why am I recommending the game? Because it is fun, granted it isn't a technical masterpeice and it's graphics don't even surpass those of previous House of the Dead Games (3 onwards) but it is enjoyable to play and in the end it can even be educational. (If only to an extent due to the vulgarity!)
I would say, if the list of cons has really put you off the game then wait until it is on a deep discount.

reviewText:
I should have wrote this review long time ago after i bought the game, being a huge huge fan of The House of The Dead series, i bought this game with the intent of being able to play another entry on the PC and i was not disappointed again.

This game is the port of the PS3 version, so if you have played it on the PS3 you will notice it will be similiar and for those who played the Wii version you will find it completely different.

Gameplay will get repetitive as it would be the same 9 stages over and over again that you will be playing, if you do not like the repetitive gameplay then you will find yourself bored very fast.
But because theres the shooting mode included, i will sort of say this game is worth more getting than the PS3 or the Wii Version (Which i own both), with the added benefit of being able to play with a online friend.

If you are a big fan of the series like i am or are just looking for a unique zombie 'typing' experience , then you should defintely get this game as well as it will provide you a couple of fun hours of on-rail typing/shooting experience.

Bought it at full price and defintely did not regret buying it.

10/10 Would suffer like G did

reviewText:
The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is certainly a game wrapped inside it's own niche little genre. If you want a Zombie Type-em-up / B-Grade Horror Movie / Reboot of a 2000 Dreamcast game, then this is your only option.

But it's not a bad option at all. What it does, it does very well, while being very tongue-in-cheek about it.

If you've ever played any House of the Dead game, then you'll feel right at home. This game is ported from the remake; House of the Dead: Overkill. There's one key" difference
date: in that you swap out your light gun for your keyboard. I know
recommended: right? I've always thought words were more powerful than weapons.\n\nAs you progress through a level (on the rails)
hoursPlayed: you'll see various zombies ambling their way towards you
voteText: accompanied with words or even long phrases. All you gotta do it type a word/phrase at a time to kill the zombies. Easy. But
helpfulPercent: when they start to pile up on screen
votesHelpful: getting ever closer
votesTotal: panic starts to settle in. You can easily be overcome.\n\nNot only that
votesFunny: but you could get distracted by the chuckle-worthy phrases that do pop up. I don't want to shoot a zombie that has the words FREE HUGS under it!\n\nThis game could aim for an educational purpose
commentsCount: helping people to touch-type
column16: if only it wasn't for its non-family-friendly look.\n\nThe Typing of the Dead: Overkill is an overall good game with a unique mechanic. Just don't come looking here for a deep story or compelling drama. Just expect to type words at zombies for a few hours. And hey
column17: there's nothing wrong with that."

reviewText:
The game is a lot of fun with a rude and off the wall sense of humour, superb music and also includes an 'on the rails' shooter mode if you are not in the mood for typing.

ATI/AMD graphics users be warned though. The latest driver causes the zombies to glitch and sometimes become partly invisible. This doesn't affect gameplay too much in the typing mode but obviously does in the shooter mode. And regardless it's still annoying that no fix appears to be on the horizon from Sega. Whilst with AMD, who knows?

Apparantly it only affects users of the ATI/AMD cards of generation 6000HD series and above. And an older driver still works. If you have an Nvidia card go for it! Otherwise just be aware of this issue.

reviewText: Probably helps those who are still learning to type faster on the keyboard a lot. Although the excessive swearing and cursing is pretty over the top and gets old really fast. One thing that bothers me the most is that all the available DLCs do is replace the text in the game with quotes from literature and other media. No new enemies. No new levels. Nothing. Just text. And for some reason, each of them costs about $2.99? Please tell me why I should pay $2.99 to enjoy Shakespeare's work in an on-rail zombie typing/shooting game. An appropriate analogy would be having to pay $2.99 to replace the green pipes in Mario with red recolored ones. Completely relevant.\n\nBut other than that, in general it's a very fun game, but not fun enough to justify its pricing. You might wanna wait for a discount offer to get it.

reviewText: So long as you're willing to run with the over-the-top Tongue in Cheek B-Movie humor  and aren't offended by the literal hundreds of profanity, you will love this game. It isn't going to teach you typing, but it does make the game easier than the shooting version (although that's included as well in case you have a PC compatible light gun). The story is pure B cheese, but the shooting is good, and the scoring mechanism rewards accuracy. There are 9 levels, plus some mini-games, which all told can be played through in about 3-4 hours. But it's quite a ride; I've played through it on the Wii, the PS3 and the Typing Version, and loved it every time.

reviewText: The Typing of The Dead: Overkill is a fun little typing arcade game that may or may not make you a better typer. I can't say for certain if playing this game will help you in that respect, as it only ever made me realise how bad I was. That doesn't mean it isn't fun, however. The game's ridiculously repugnant story takes you through every cliché in the book as two buddy cops fight their way through a horde of zombies mutants in this 1970's b-movie inspired schlock. The humour probably won't please everyone, so you have to ask yourself if you can enjoy something that's so bad it's good". The dialogue and voice acting are hammier than Resident Evil

reviewText:
Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-GZprB5vXXo

The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is the end result of The House of the Dead Overkill moving from a Wii title, to a PS3 title and finally making it's way to PC. It also is the latest iteration of the tradition of changing the gameplay from point-and-shoot into typing tutor, while changing almost nothing else about the game.

Everything is very over the top grindhouse horror with stuff that at times even makes my stomach turn a bit.. and it's hilarious. If this sounds up your alley, TOTDO may be worth the price for you. Just don't get your hopes up on the minigames or multiplayer keeping your interest after the main campaign.. at best, the inclusion of the original game with mouse shooting controls might be fun. Tapping keys at duck shoot targets and dying constantly as you and your friend type over each other's words in crippling lag? Not so much.

3/5 Is it on sale?""

reviewText: Taking the formula of the original Typing of the Dead and putting it into the Typing Of The Dead Overkill game is not a bad thing. It's a nice game to practice typing skills with, or just relax while blasting away some zombies while making your keyboard sound like a machinegun.\n\nThere are, however, downsides to this iteration of the series. There are no mid-level missions like Kill X zombies in Y seconds" or branching paths. Also sadly missing is the breakdown of how you did compared to previous runs. Gone also are the rank per kill depending on typing speed. And compared to House of the Dead 2 (Typing of the dead)
date: there are more cutscenes which go on for longer. Not that any of these points are downright bad things
recommended: but they're different enough that you may want to consider if this is the entry for you.\n\nInstead of per-kill ranking which will give you different scores depending on the speed of your typing
hoursPlayed: instead you're expected to get a "goregasm" running. Basically a long combo without getting hit or making mistakes.\nAlso it's now possible to do headshots in the regular mode. With each zombie to kill you may make one mistake. While it will not count as a headshot and will thus give you less points
voteText: it will still allow you to carry on your score multiplier.\nThere is a Hardcore mode you can enable though which turns the difficulty up. When enabled any mistake will not only reset your multiplier immediately
helpfulPercent: it'll also give the zombie you were shooting a whole new word
votesHelpful: forcing you to start over. And just to further up the difficulty: While normal mode doesn't care about punctuation
votesTotal: spaces and caps
votesFunny: Hardcode requires you to not only type perfectly
commentsCount: but also use shift
column16: space and various punctuation. A step up in difficulty from the original House of the Dead.\n\nThe House of the Dead series has never been a particularly well told series
column17: relying on plenty of cheese to go through the cutscenes. This entry however seems to ditch the downright silly plotline in favour of a grindhouse style story with an ever swearing bada** cop and A mysterious secret agent
column18: oh and of course the tough as nails chick making an appearance a few times. If you can enjoy the swearing and general parody on this kind of movie you might find yourself enjoying the plotline of the game. If not you'll be cringing often
column19: or feeling downright bored and hitting the key to skip the cutscenes as soon as possible.\n\nAlso included is the original House Of The Dead Overkill game
column20: though controlled with mouse instead of light gun. And this mode still has the Director's Cut mode which extends the levels considerably. This mode is sadly missing from the typing part of the game.\n\nIn all
column21: The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a fun distraction if you like typing games. It's not as boring as many other typing tutors. The sentences typed aren't as unintentionally hillarious as the original game. In my opinion
column22: it's a step to the side rather than a significant step forward or backwards in the series.\nI can recommend it to those who want a bit more variety than the original Typing of the Dead
column23: and to anyone who wants to try the series and can't find the original. However it is by no means a game you must own
column24: merely a fun dictraction if you like to type."

reviewText:
I decided to buy Typing of the Dead: Overkill since it was on sale for nearly nothing. My previous experiences with the series had consisted of me playing the first two games of the series alongside my brother with a really crappy computer years ago using a dual mouse setup. It had already been quite long but i still remembered how we spent hours upon hours shooting the hordes of undead (err, mutants) back to the grave and shouting at each other to cover our backs.

Upon launching the game a wave of nostalgia came crashing down to me, as if it was a warm welcome to a home you had spent your entire childhood running around in. Absolutely nothing has changed in this release, it might have different levels and story but the gameplay is spot-on identical to what the original titles were. It's missing the dual mouse support (And actually, local multiplayer isn't even supported although you can go online with your friends.) but that's something that most likely will not annoy you since the gameplay is so, damn, perfect.

The game consists of you trying to type sentences that are placed on the top of the zombies' heads, and after completing each sentence the creature dies. It's extremely fun and fast paced, and is something someone would even go as far to call a rhythm game. On top of that, it's even educational, yes, killing zombies can be smart! If you're someone who hasn't never really gotten into fast writing, then this game is a very powerful tool to make you learn the quirks. There are even some tutorials online from the older title to help you get on it quickly.

Soundtrack in ToD:O is pretty good, it's mostly your basic bar rock" stuff that you wont remember after turning the game off
date: but it gets the job done. Sound assets and graphics in the title are basic to say the least
recommended: you'll be hearing the same grunts and sounds a lot
hoursPlayed: and the zombie models are re-used quite a bit. Maybe even to a level that it might start irritating you. The game also sports a bare minimal options menu
voteText: in which you only have the option to change resolution
helpfulPercent: AA
votesHelpful: and gamma settings. It's not a visually stunning experience but a bit more variability would have always been nice.\n\nContent wise the game is extraordinary
votesTotal: after finishing the story/arcade mode you'll unlock the hardcore mode which makes everything harder. You can also play the original House of the Dead: Overkill in this release
votesFunny: in which you can use your mouse or gamepad to shoot the zombies as you would in the arcades. And last but not least
commentsCount: they also decided to add a crap-ton of unlockables and minigames to keep you busy. I havent had the time to test it all
column16: but i'm pretty sure something so mechanically perfect can be nothing less than enjoyable.\n\nBut all in all
column17: even though it does have some shortcomings in term of the technical standpoint. It's a really good title that's jam packed to the brim with content that will keep you enjoyed for a long time."

reviewText:
Hope you know how to spell and type without looking at your fingers, because otherwise you’re dead. In the Typing of the Dead: Overkill - a typing-themed version of on-rails shooter House of the Dead: Overkill - the light-gun is replaced with a keyboard. Zombies shamble towards you with words or phrases in front of them, which you need to type out quickly and accurately before they eat you and your fumbling digits.

This isn’t the first time a House of the Dead game has been turned into a typing tutor: it’s the same premise as the Dreamcast cult classic Typing of the Dead (1999). It’s a strange mix that works well: the goofy nature of the story and “grindhouse” aesthetic combined with comedic words at inappropriate times. While Overkill by itself was an average lightgun game, this typing iteration comes across better. It’s got a funky soundtrack, multiple difficulty levels, full Steam integration, and two-player cooperative play arrives later as free DLC. Boss encounters have been especially tweaked to better utilize the new input method.

As a bonus, the game contains the full Extended Cut of the PlayStation 3 version of Overkill, playable with a mouse or controller. Extended Cut was a re-release of the original Wii version, with improved visuals, two new levels and a bunch of tiny tweaks.

date: it does actually teach you to be a better and faster typer. I became a phenomenal typer on the original Typing of the Dead.  This version is even better because it's modern so you don't have to put up with old crappy graphics.  You can play through the game with the mouse as an straight forward FPS
recommended: but it's not why this is worth buying.  Seriously.  Play it for an hour once a week.  Your typing will improve.  Guaranteed."

reviewText:
If I had this instead of Mavis Beacon in the 9th grade, I'd probably be  able to type at 60 wpm!
This is a fantastic update (ok, sequel?) to the original Typing of the Dead, which was really only available for Dreamcast, and that required the DC Keyboard, which you probably only had if (like me) you were heavily into Phantasy Star Online.
Gameplay: on-rails light-gun shooter, where instead of shooting with a gun, you type words. Not just any words, though, this game had some clever writers. There are countless times when a word, combined with a specific enemy and/or situation, will give you a good laugh.
As the original Typing of the Dead was a skin" of sorts to House of the Dead 2
date: this game utilizes House of the Dead Overkill
recommended: which basically takes a grindhouse/"directed by Rob Zombie" aesthetic and runs with its lovably cheesy and over-the-top plot throughout several stages.\nLooking for a fun way to boost those typing skills
hoursPlayed: or looking for a few good laughs? Definitely check it out.\nNot into typing? It also includes the shooter version of HotD: Overkill! Ya can't go wrong!"

reviewText:
Have you watched Planet Terror (2007)? If you haven't, a quick heads up: it's an homage to old grindhouse movies, low budget explotation made in the 70's, full of sex and violence. If a dude puking his own intestines in gruesome detailed fashion, a dog getting run over by an armored truck or a doctor moving Fergie's head, revealing her brains have been eaten by zombies mutants is something you may find amusing, I suggest a watch.

Now, onto the game...
It's a House of the Dead game, so the gameplay is simple: you shoot zombies, they die, you fight a boss with a different mechanic at the end of the level, and bam, that's it. It's an on-rails shooter. While the older games had a rather paranormal feel this one is inspired in the movie above mentioned and the films that precede it. It's a funny and gory take on the zombie mutant outbreak. The characters are stereotyped yet not cliched, the screen get a nice messy filming filter and the music in funky as hell (well, except on the bosses, it gets a bit dubsteppy for my tastes).

Here's an example quote:

Originally posted by Papa Caesar:(Being suave as hell) As you well know, Isaac, I enjoy pain. It's like a good chinese dinner, you know, with the sweet and the sour. Expanding on that analogy, I will smile with delight—that's the sweet—as you scream for your ♥♥♥♥ing life—of course, that's the sour.
The kind of novel part is that you type instead of shoot. It was done before in The Typing of the Dead, which was a twist on the second game in the series. Everytime a zombie pops up on the screen, you have to type the corresponding word or phrase (depending on the difficulty) fast enough so you don't get killed, or type certain letter in a QTE fashion. The default dictionary used by the game uses some amusing words related to the level you're playing in, such as nasty medical terms in the hospital level and such. A nice addition is the use of the workshop for dictionaries, which can be as helpful (different language) as funny (memes, hentai phrases). There's also paid dlc for the game, including shakespeare, sci-fi and others.

The original The House of the Dead: Overkill (2009) was released for the Wii, with the extended cut coming to PS3 a few years later adding better graphics and two new levels. This version of the game is virtually the same as the enhanced PS3 version, with the added typing gameplay. In fact, you can switch from the two versions in the main menu. The game consist of 9 levels, with three difficulty settings and well as an unlockable hardcore mode. You can also play the House" shooter version

reviewText:
I love all of the House of the Dead games, and this one is no different. In fact, it may be my favorite one, surpassing even House of the Dead 4: Special Edition.

Pros:
-Challenging (Tip: Priority is key)
-Hilarious! The F-Bomb supposedly makes up for a whopping 3% of all dialogue and was in Guiness World Records for most swears in a video game.
-Great characters and dirty villains. Love Agent G, Isaac Washington, Varla, etc. And Clement Darlings is one of the most ♥♥♥♥ed up villains I've ever seen in a game.
-It also has the option to use the mouse instead of a keyboard, which is another bonus.
-Great bosses. (And for the first time their names aren't Tarot cards)
-Catchy soundtrack.
-Sickening violence just the way I like it.
-Surprisingly for a spinoff, it has a decent story.


Cons:
The one thing I have to complain is that sometimes as soon as the camera turns you are hit by a mutant behind you. Before your brain even processes anything, a zombie takes my health away. It may be a glitch, but I don't know. It's really frustrating sometimes, especially if I have Goregasm.

All in all, great game. I definitely recommend this game. 9.9/10.

reviewText: The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is an offbeat first-person puzzle-action game for the PC that lets you fight hordes of gruesome zombies by quickly typing out words that appear onscreen. This unusual game actually has a history: It originally debuted on Sega's Dreamcast console in 2000 and was itself a modified version of Sega's previously released light-gun arcade game, The House of the Dead 2.\nAs with most light-gun games, The Typing of the Dead is played on rails"--that is
date: you can't actually move your character or choose where to go next; the game determines that. However
recommended: depending on how quickly you defeat your enemies
hoursPlayed: you may be able to rescue innocent bystanders
voteText: uncover bonus items
helpfulPercent: and choose alternate paths through a level
votesHelpful: though you'll always finish each level by fighting a powerful boss monster. These boss monsters will actually challenge you in a few interesting ways. For instance
votesTotal: one will force you to figure out and type in the correct answer to a simple question
votesFunny: while another will come barreling at you with a giant chainsaw and will strike you if you can't type out a full sentence in time.\nThe Typing of the Dead is an unusual game that might not have amazing graphics or sound
commentsCount: but its gameplay is unique and extremely fun. Despite its strange
column16: silly premise
column17: it does have a few explicitly gory sequences--some zombies turn into sloppy messes when shot down
column18: which is why it's an M-rated game. But if you like action-packed games or horror movies
column19: you'll probably enjoy The Typing of the Dead...and even if you don't
column20: you might want to give it a try."

reviewText:
Played this with my buddy Crowley. First off it is SEEEEGGGAAAAAAAA! and you can't go wrong with that, right?

Story: It is so riduculous, there were parts me and my friend could not stop laughing!!! It didn't always make sense, but who cares it was hilarious. Very vintage 70's classic cheesy theme to it. Also remember this game is not for kids lol no not at all I don't even think the game is for adults.

Sountrack: Amazing soundtrack every song in it is just awesome. One thing Sega knows how to do is give kickass music to their gameplay.

Graphics: NOTHING! NOTHING! NOTHING! NOTHING! When you have nothing good to say just say NOTHING! (typing of the dead joke). Gotta admit it is the worst part of the game. Way too many glitches and it just felt gross. It wasn't something you would expect in 2013... maybe 2003.

8/10 good game to play in fun factor, but I wouldn't show it off to everyone only people who have a very dark humor.

reviewText:
I like the idea of a typing tutor game. I like even more when you can go head to head with friends in a co-op mode to see who can type more words per minute.

The story is alright. It's a comedy in the style of an old grindhouse action film. The humor doesn't always hit it's mark and sometimes goes a bit overboard with a joke until it's been beaten into the ground. It assumes every one of it's jokes is a riot and proceeds to keep doing those same jokes ad nauseum. There are a few jokes that hit the mark but they're few and far between.

The game itself is buggy as heck. Co-op partners are prone to disconnecting from each other. And the game will occationally freeze for no reason. It has a lot that should have been ironed out and never was.

Overall I enjoy the game but I'd completly understand if someone hated it. I uninstalled it after beating the story once because co-oping was extreamly tedious due to dropped connections that were caused by the game itself.

reviewText:
Well, if you ever liked typing games, and zombie games, youre most definitely 100% going ot like this. It has a corny 70s cop show style storyline and videos to match. The main characters are straight out of a Dolemite movie. It has boss fights, items/power-ups you can grab along the way, humorous words to type.
The thing im liking most about this is, im an extremely fast typer, but i have trouble not looking at the keyboard. I dont type the way they taught me in school with my fingers positioned onmt he right buttons and such because that never worked for me, i type slow when i do it that way. For the most part i know where the ksy are, but i still need to sneak a peek at the keyboard to type a lot correctly. I feel like if i keep playing this game it will cure that, and i will no longer have to look at the keyboard to type. You have to be fast to survive in this game, otherwise youre going to die quick.

My recommendation is, if you are an at least semi-fast typer as it is, go ahead and grab this game, it will make you even faster.
If you are a slow typer, just forget it, because youre never going to even get past the first level, and its going ot frustrate the hell out of you, although if your hearts in it i guess you could use htis as a tool to learn how to type fast.

all in all, on a scale of 1 through 10 i would give this a 9/10.

reviewText: Have you ever wanted to kill some zombies, or rather mutants with your keyboard? No no, not like that. Use your words! Seriously though, type the living hell out of those creatures for a load of fun. The story is rather short, but there is a multiplayer option alongside of a leaderboard to see just how great (or pitiful) you really are compared to the rest of the world. Luckily though, the story is humorous, cheesy, and rather compelling for some reason. While it can be quite crude and rather silly, it is probably worth the laugh. The mechanics are simple, however it can be challenging given that you can type only a wee bit faster than a turtle can walk. Everybody is bound to have some sort of fun with this title! Really though, name a person who doesn't want to write a novel in order to kill a zombie, err, mutant. The graphics have improved a bit from the Wii port of House of the Dead: Overkill, which by the way is included in this purchase. The mechanics for that, however, are odd considering that you do not have a motion controller and must point and click to shoot. It's definitely a decent buy for fans of the series, and is definitely worth buying, but if you'd rather have a gun in hand and shoot your CRT television set with lasers, I would recommend playing the original few games. If you like typing your problems away, well, play this or the original Typing of the Dead on the Sega Dreamcast! Good luck surviving to all of the slow typers in the world; happy hunting!

reviewText:
Awesome game! Dark humor, interesting/funny story, tons of swearing and lots of gore! Playable with keyboard or mouse.

This review will be split in 2 parts as there are 2 different ways to play:

The Typing of the Dead: Overkill.

The whole point of the game is to type the words as fast as you can, while prioritizing whatever is coming at you first ( projectiles, mutants, etc. ) It's pretty basic in that aspect but nonetheless, very fun. Also you have to keep your eyes open for bonuses and collectibles! I'm sure this game would greatly improve your typing speed if you play it alot. Mixing typing and a video game together makes it surprisingly addictive if you like those 2 things.

I do type 120 words+ a minute and ''medium'' and ''hard'' difficulties are both just right for me. I can tell that there is not that much difference between the 2, but it is not as easy as I thought it would be, I didin't complete a level perfectly yet and i'm currently trying to do that. The ''easy'' mode is probably fine for almost everybody who can type without looking at a keyboard. I only played it once to test it and it was alot easier than the other modes.

In the end, the story mode took me 2 hours 30 minutes to finish, which is pretty short, but there's other stuff to do in the game anyways! Such as Mini-games, House of the Dead, Hardcore-mode... Etc.

-------

The House of the Dead: Overkill.

I was really surprised by this. The game actually has the whole story mode, playable with the mouse, just like the good old House of the Dead! Even the mini-games, challenges and more are playable with the mouse!

You even have a gun shop, you gain gold while playing and you can upgrade your guns ( 5 upgrades per gun with 2 levels each ) and there is 6+ weapons.

I found the accuracy to be pretty harsh with the automatic guns... Guess I should have sticked to pistol, but oh well. The story is really different with a mouse, the bosses are not played the same way and if you are better at FPS games than you are at typing on a keyboard, this mode will be easier for you.

-------

Overall, I recommend this game, the few bugs I have found so far weres not being able to shoot 2 mutants, after I used a grenade on them in the House of the Dead, sound clips missing during slow-mos and Rage mutant finishing blows, game closing and re-opening itself after typing a word, the rest of the levels played just fine.

reviewText:
Overall I'm pretty disappointed with this game, comparing it to the original Typing of the Dead.

There are many graphical and audio glitches that occur throughout the game, and the lack of settings is also disappointing. Game is locked to a 16:9 aspect ratio and you can't change the resolution to another aspect ratio, so I have to play in windowed mode at a very low resolution so that nothing is cut off.

Gameplay is alright, but nothing special. Would have been better if there was more variety in the weapons or less predicatble boss battles. Oh, and the final boss is completely out of line with the rest of the game, really weird mechanic for defeating it. I kind of get what they were trying to do but they executed it very poorly.

Characters are annoying as hell, the dialogue makes my ears bleed. The story was written by a fourth grader for his first english class assignment, and character development is non existent. I didn't buy this game for an in depth story, but just an FYI that there is none.

The mini games are fun for a couple minutes, there is one where you fight wave by wave, which is kind of what I was hoping for to be honest.

Would not recommend this game at full price of $20, no way. Maybe if it goes on sale for $5 you should pick it up. You're better off playing the original Typing of the Dead instead, maybe one day they'll bring that to Steam.

It even has a focus mode built in: Alt+Tab while playing the game will close the game making you lose the progress you are doing. You can't get that from other cheap typing software!
Do you have an archaic computer? LOL, you're in luck. All those hipsters with new computers will need to enable Run this program in compatibility for Windows XP SP3" and probably download a .dll to be able to play it. How's that for value!

What are you waiting for? Go buy it now! /s"

reviewText: The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a hilarious, rail-shooter game where you type your enemies to death while you listen to your partner drop the F-Bomb every two seconds. This game will not only challenge your typing speed, but also your accuracy. If you can’t type without looking at the keyboard, you’re basically screwed. Luckily, The Typing of the Dead: Overkill includes the original game in which you use your mouse to shoot instead of type. The game is only about 4 hours long, but it is a hell lot of fun. It has a ridiculous storyline which will keep you interested and leave you craving for more. If you’re a fan of typing games or want to improve your typing skills, you should definitely buy this game. 8/10

reviewText:
I bought The Typing of The Dead: Overkill during Steam Summer Sale 2015. I was originally quite hesitant to spending more than $5 on a game since I rarely do so. But I remembered how much fun I had in my friend's basement playing House of the Dead 2 on his Dreamcast. So I pulled the trigger and bought it.

Holy ♥♥♥♥.

This game was more than what I expected from a game for this price (<$10).

The humor, the gameplay that brings back memories, and the educational value that comes from The Typing of The Dead: Overkill makes this game, by far, the best purchase of 2015 for me.

Am I hyping it? Probably.
Nevertheless, if you have ever played House of the Dead 2 and enjoyed the game, I highly suggest playing this game.

If you suck at typing, perhaps this game will make you a better typer as well.

reviewText:
Okay I need to write two reviews for this game.

If you use NVIDEA then please read the following:
The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a great game, the story is interesting and hilarious, and its great fun to challenge yourself to type ridiculous things as fast as you can.

Along side the main game there is also The House of the Dead which reminds me of arcade shooters, the more money you earn the better guns and upgrades you can purchase which ultimately will help you progress through the different chapters and attempt to get all the achievements for this section.

Plus there are three mini games of varying fun too!

If you have AMD read the above and the following:
Alright so I clearly love this game a lot, I've got all the achievements for The Typing of the Dead and slowly getting the ones for The House of the Dead but there is a huge downside to this game too, which from what I can gather is an issue primarily for AMD.

The mutants bodys, heads, and/or limbs can be invisible.

Its annoying. It makes it harder to judge which sentence you should be typing first to make sure you take no damage, but it is still doable. However for The House of the Dead and shooting the mostly invisible mutants is a pain in the gorram ♥♥♥.

I've read that a few people have been able to fix this bug but so far I haven't been able to do that.

reviewText:
Everything you need to know about this game can be neatly summed up in the title alone. Typing of the Dead: Overkill is one bloody brilliant throwback to the kitsch Zombi-...err...mutant...films of the 70's and 80's of course it plays up almost every aspect of these films and the result is an extremely OTT hop,skip and jump through a gore filled grindhouse fest that left me laughing more or less from start to finish.

This game includes both the typing version and the bog standard *Click and shoot* original so theres certainly a good few hours of gameplay here if you want to unlock all the achievements by playing both games. The dialogue is comedy gold and the controls are precise. you rarely feel cheated while playing, though the game will often get the odd cheap shot in by putting a Mutant right on the other side of a door which, as your on a rail (Its a rail shooter) will occassionally score a cheap knock of damage.

Graphically...it's a sega Zombie shoot-em-up based on an Arcade machine of the same name...it's never going to look cutting edge...but it's good enough certainly (Though it does suffer somewhat from bad to no lip synching on dialogue)

Personally, if you've already played the likes of Left4Dead2 and are looking for a new challenge or if you just have utter nostalgia for the days you could find games like Time Crisis in any arcade or fast food place This game is a perfect addition to your Steam Library, while I cant say it's the best Zombie game out there, in the case of this game I would argue that it isnt a point. This is the Cheeseburger of Zombie games...and sometimes; you just need a cheeseburger in your life.

reviewText:
Typing of the Dead is completely nuts. Within a few minutes of playing you're presented with a story and visuals in the style of a hilariously bad B-movie, with dialogue that is just so utterly ridiculous you can't help but laugh. And if that wasn't all, some of the words and phrases you get to type are just hilarious on their own (which means it's highly recommended to get the DLC packs, especially the ones with the dirty bits).

The most hilarious bit though is that the only gripe I have with the game (aside from some loading times that could be better) is that the plain ol' House of the Dead is in here. And playing House of the Dead is a little bit... boring. On PC, all you do in House of the Dead is point and click. It makes you realize that Typing of the Dead is a much better fit for PC.

Typing of the Dead is a surprisingly entertaining game, it's surprisingly funny as well, and yes, it is *technically* educational. It's a win-win-win.

reviewText:
I usually dont make any reviews here, but this game deserve it.

- In this one, you have both Type of the dead and House of the dead, so you can choose type or shoot to kill the mutants (yeah they r mutants)
- FANTASTIC story like Sin City and Pulp Fiction style, with unique humor
- Great characters with great personality
- Nice action along the stages AND when you unlock the director´s cut mode, you can do the whole game again in another perspective of the stage, its awesome !!! (note: you take alternative ways but some are exactly the same as the main mission)
- Lots of collectable stuff to shoot and unlock 3d models, pics, and a TOTALLY AWESOME COMIC BOOK that teaches you what happened before the game starts line, in the models of the Sin City !
- BLOWING MIND SOUNDTRACK. Its nice, its hot and its incredible done.

The only thing that i can point negative its the multiplayer. I tried a few times jump on it but no sucess. But, if you have a friend you can easy invite a friend for a match.

Graphics : 8/10 (nothing personal here, just not the new generations of graphics)
Sound : 10/10
History Plot : 10/10
Characters : 10/10
Fun : 10/10
Gameplay : 9/10 (its great, but sometimes when you need to shot and object to unlock a collectable, man... you need to memorize the thing cuz some of then are barelly impossible to blow at the first time)

reviewText:
I bought The Typing of The Dead: Overkill during Steam Summer Sale 2015. I was originally quite hesitant to spending more than $5 on a game since I rarely do so. Holy ♥♥♥♥.

The humor, the gameplay that brings back memories, and the educational value that comes from The Typing of The Dead: Overkill makes this game, by far, the best purchase of 2015 for me.

If you suck at typing, perhaps this game will make you a better typer as well.

reviewText:
I ended up enjoying everything about this game a whole bunch less than the first Typing of the Dead on Dreamcast.

That game had:
A fun sense of self-parody -- zombies attack with frying pans and plastic mallets. Human characters actually fight by typing on keyboards strapped to their bodies.
A combo system that rewarded you for not making any typos.
Two player local co op.
Bosses with unique gimmicks.
Additional challenge modes.

This game has:
None of that.

reviewText:
Good points missing, bad things introduced.

If you've played the previous games in the series like I have, you would probably have high expectations from this game. Equally possible, however, is the disappointment that you may find. The previous ToD I and II were truly awesome games with a thoughtful design of gameplay and at the same time focused on their educational aspect. Unfortunately much of their these are actually missing in this installment.

For starters, in this game you won't find any keyboards and Dreamcasts, which were just signatures for the previous game. Also missing were the items like molotov cocktails available for pick up, which added fun and could be life-savers. In place of these were concept arts, audio tracks, 3D models which are unlockable. Worse still, these are not collected by typing certain letters or words like you would in the previous games, but by pressing TAB key, which is rather meaningless. As these are not as noticeable as they should, this could mean that you may be better off just to press TAB key every now and then. In-game challenges (e.g. defeat 30 zombies) with rewards are also non-existent. Maintaining combos only gets your a better score instead of life bonuses. Gameplay is also straightforward without twists like answering a question as in the previous games.

Compared to the previous installments, this game is rather easy at NORMAL or HARD difficulty. But the hardcore mode, which put emphasis on accuracy, could on the other hand be too hard. In this mode, if you make a mistake in the middle of a word then the phrase would change and you will have to start over again. You would also have to type spaces, which you may find quite annoying if you're used to the previous games or the non-hardcore mode. To make things worse, if you are too slow the zombies would just keep attacking you, unlike in the previous games where they would slow down after you lost a life and give you a chance to pick up momentum again. This, coupled with the fact that you have to restart when miss, could cost you two or three lives when you make a single mistake, which could be rather frustrating. In addition, I've been in times when I noticed my mistake only after a few letters, only to know that I was already locked on the new phrase(s) which contained some same letters, which could be very confusing as I was wondering where I was. Although it could have been a good idea to require spaces as in the real world, the game failed in this aspect by not having any visual cues for spaces. Therefore I am always wondering if I've typed the spaces as I am so used to the previous games, and have lost many lives either because I had to stop and think or because I remembered it wrong, which means retyping the phrase. Another problem is the difficulty to figure out which text box corresponds to the zombie closest to you. At times I have to wait until the box changes to red before I could be sure, which could be too late. If you've noticed, in the previous installments the words got harder if you were doing well and vice versa, which kept you always under pressure to improve. It is not the case in this game.

The game offers unlimited credits at the cost of half your score, which I find not as challenging as the previous games. Also, as long as you finish a level you will unlock the next, no matter what difficulty you attempted. The minigames are somewhat cosmetic and meaningless, instead of focus on a particular area (e.g. accuracy, reflexes, special keys) helping you to improve.

All in all, this game did not inherit much of the merits from the previous games and boils down to a dull and repetitive gameplay with a few nuisances. That said, I suppose the game is not that bad if you forget the previous installments.

reviewText:
I don’t know if I am the only one who played the original The Typing Of The Dead that was released on 2000 but it shames me not to state that as hilarious as that game’s voice acting was it was still a very effective teaching tool for me. Prior to that game I was a “search and peck” (looked and the keyboard looking for the key to press, press it then search for the next letter in the work I wished to type) but just after a few days I found myself typing without looking down.

The original game began with step #1 like any typing game/program does and that is with the basic “A S D F” on your left hand and “J K L ;” on your right hand. The game will then show you what keys you hit with great accuracy and what keys you have trouble with. (Not everyone knows this or have even noticed the small raised line or dot on the “F” and “J” keys on the keyboards) You could only imagine my confusion as to why would any typing game never mind a sequel to the typing of the dead would overlook this very basic of basis!  At the very least the first mission on its lowest difficulty could have been used to learn the ASDF and JKL; keys before the player is expected to type “Jasper V2”

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=238769932

…But what if this is not supposed to be something to help your typing skills?
Although the original was hilarious due to its poor voice acting, this game not funny because of the excessive searing. Every single cut scene from this game (including the very first one) has someone saying Mother F*cker, Sh*t, F*ck and so on. You could swear it was written by a 12 year old.

At the very least the mode where you use your mouse to shoot a gun is fun, this should have been the original basis for the game since they face planted with the typing version.

PS: I am proud to say I am now a very efficient typist, I am just very disappointed in how far my tutor's series has fallen.

The game have potential, but in this state, definitely not recommended.

Summarizing, unless you are a 10 year old who is discovering violence, girls, and videogames for the first time in your life, avoid this game. It is a waste of time.

reviewText:
Unexpectedly, the game DOES make you a better typer - especially when it comes to the symbols above the numbers (on a standard laptop keyboard).

The story is intentionally campy but quite funny, and the type-to-kill gameplay is solid. The only part I didn't enjoy so much was the last boss fight, as it had you guessing for terms in what should have been a fast-paced fight.

Also, getting this game also gives you access to the original shooter this was based on: House of The Dead: Overkill. Really good value.

reviewText:
I used to love The Typing of The Dead - the original game was low-poly, high on (sometimes inadvertent) humour and light hearted generally. It was fun!

This game, on the other hand, hasn't benefited from the polished graphics. The move toward more realistic zombies hasn't really done it for me, and to be honest the setting felt a bit too dark and miserable for my liking. The humour there was felt forced.
The frequent swears from the characters was unwanted.
The final nail in the coffin was the oversexualised and under-dressed female characters - an unecessary element that added nothing to the game and I felt was unhelful.
There were some enjoyable bits (I like typing!) but on the whole I got to the end of the second level and felt uncomfortable enough to not want to play on.

Sorry, Typing of the Dead - I was looking forward to you, but you're just not as good as the original.

reviewText:
If The Typing of the Dead: Overkill doesn't kill your enthusiasm the first playthrough, it will the next.

Pros: Graphics, Sounds, Controls
Cons: Story, Gameplay, Repetitive, DLC

The Typing of The Dead: Overkill sports the best graphics of any Houe of the Dead title.  The sound and voice acting match well.  Controls are perfect (they should be) when typing, but fall short when actually shooting.

Ironically, the ironically over-the-top story will keep many away.  Those that are mature enough to appreciate it will likely quit the game, and those that aren't will likely ape its puny lexicon. In other words, it's ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥.  The gameplay begins to grind after the first few episodes and it's extremely unlikely to improve your typing.  The classic and Director's Cut modes only worsen the matter, as do the grindy achievements.

Dictionaries are only available as DLC because you could have someone putting something in there that would be particularly unpleasant
date:
but The Typing of The Dead: Overkill has the Guiness World Record as the most profane video game in history.

The next dictionary needs a new word: hipocrisy.

6/10

reviewText:
I have played this game on the Wii (yes, the game with the second most amount of swears in a video game is on the wii) and I can safely say this game is great, and looks great, and feels great. It attempts to recreate a cheesy 70's film, and it does it immensely well.

I do have 2 problems with it though, only minor.
a) The original typing of the dead could be played by all ages, because it had no swears and the zombies weren't scary.. This game, however is the complete opposite. I can't even describe the amount of adult content in this game, which is a shame, because this is a very effective way to teach typing by giving them a fun game to play while teaching real skills.
b) They don't have dreamcasts, dreamcast keyboards, or oversized batteries on the characters, which is the worst thing ever.

Pick it up during a sale, ignore the DLC because it doesn't seem worth it in my eyes.

reviewText: A hilarious game made even more hilarious. A game inspired by the keyboard learning games of old, including the original Typing Of The Dead. The game does make you spell out some odd things that you will certainly not be used in keyboard tutorials. While this may sound like it's turned the original game into a very easy game, trying to type down the needed words and phrases while being attacked by zombies can put on some stress and cause mistakes. But overall it is a very fun experience. Also the game does contain the original House Of The Dead Overkill that was on the Wii and PS3 and if you enjoyed it then you'll enjoy it here and if you've not played it then there's no better way to buy this game. Which I highly recommend you do.

reviewText:
Remember The House of The Dead typing game? Well this is the adult 18 rated version that's packed with plenty of profanity & gore.


The story plays out like a parody of old grindhouse films, its amusing but the near constant f-bombs & other profanity gets a bit tiring after a while.

The game will help you improve your typing skills while shooting mutants & grotesque bosses, its a bit short, finished it in an hour or so but the DLC dictionaries, rankings, co-op play & unlockable weapons,  will have you coming back for more typing antics with the odd couple Isaac Washington & Agent G.

I'd recommend this game over Mavis Beacon.

reviewText:
I used to be a big fan of Typing of the Dead. I thought it was a cool way to teach people how to type with speed and accuracy. However, this game... It's just not fun. I might not have the credibility of those who have done full run throughs or played this game for over 7 hours, but hear me out.

The most important part of any game is the first impression of it. If the first impression is not very exciting, then this game will not be very appealing towards its audience. This game has that same problem: a very weak first impression. It tries to make a very floppy story with cliche's everywhere in its comedic-satire on the whole film industry. However, that lackluster story makes this game really hard to play.

Along with, the biggest selling point to the first Typing of the Dead was that it had fun phrases that were childish, but could make you laugh. This game does not really have those, if they are later in the game then I have not seen them being that I'm only on level 4. That lack of fun, childish phrases really siphons the whole thought about the game being about learning how to type.

This game lacks the sheer fun quality to it. Am I saying that this is a bad game? No, it's just not fun. I would not recommend buying this game. I would try to find the original (if you still can) and playing that because it is much more fun than this game.

reviewText:
Having passed the game twice now I think I can write a small review for a title that I think many will overlook.

I will start off with the worst part about this game and that is it's heritage. It is a Wii game that was expanded and ported over to the PS3, which is the version that has now been ported to PC. Being originally a Wii game means that the game will not win any Best Graphics awards, but oddly enough I think this work to the games benefit. This is the only game that has captured the B-movie grindhouse feel and I think the rough graphics are a part of that. The game is also only a few hours long like any Light gun game, but the story and the way it is told is without a question better than 99% of other games in the genre.

There are two ways to play the game. The first is by typing, the other by using the mouse instead of a light gun. Typing is really good fun and gets pretty hard later into the game. Using the mouse isn't bad but it's no light gun. Since I am used to FPS games, playing with a mouse and not having control over movement was hard to get used to. Even though the game is still fun this way there were many moments of frustration when I lost a combo due to hitting nothing but air because the character moved unexpectadly. Still, it's easy to get around this. Simply be more conservative with the lead. In this mode you can buy and upgrade various weapons with money earned during a mission. A small tip, forget the slow and powerful guns, go for speed.

Since the mouse mode is good but not great the main appeal is of course Typing of the Dead and in short it is amazing. It feels alot better to type and get a gunshot sound with each letter. The number of difficulty levels for this part of the game is also great since there isn't a teaching mode. There are 3 to choose from, one is unlocked after beating the game and there is an additional modifier in the form of Hardcore mode, which can be applied to any of the standard difficulties. Hardcore mode means that you have to use the space bar and punctuation matter sure, but it also means that if you make a mistake the word changes.

There are 3 mini games for both modes. They are decent but nothing too compelling. A nice touch is the number of collectibles that can be unlocked in game. There is cocept art to find, poster to unlock, 3d Models, songs and a full length comic book. There is alot of it and it's not always easy to find them all so it's good that the game is highly replayable. I would suggest that people play the game both ways with a keyboard and mouse. The story is the same, but the control methods make it a very different experiance. I should also mention that passing the game in mouse mode unlocks a Directors Cut of the game, so there's another reason to pass it once more.

Overall this is a great gama that should not be missed. The story is fun, the typing mechanic fairly unique and very satysfying. So far I have put more hours into this than I do in for example a typical FPS games campaign and having passed the game twice now I know that I will be passing it at least once more with hardcore mode on throughout.

Edit: Just started Directors Cut and it's faster, harder and the missions themselves also seem to have more stuff. So here is another reason to pass the game=)

Pointless, mindless shooting without all the pretense. Oh and you can type, too, if that's your thing.

I would not recommend this game for people looking to improve their typing skills.  Game is 7GB download and 7GB on the hard drive.  It is larger than GTA V.  This is mostly from cut scenes. Game also moves at a very fast pace regardles of the difficulty level you select, so it is really bad for beginners.

They were obviously going for a B movie" feel but it feels forced.  This game feels like it used to be a simple mouse based shooter on rails but they made it a typing game at the last minute.

I have been looking forward to this game for ages and was excited to see it on sale to justify my purchase. However, I have sitll been unable to play. Why? So far, these have NOT worked to get a launch:
Updated graphics driver.
Adjusted the default NVIDIA graphics processer
Deleted AppData config file.
Updated DirectX

If you want to struggle to start this bugger, go ahead and purchase if you're interested. However, right now I'm saying it's not worth the headache. It is absolutely not worth full price, even if I finally get this thing to work.

reviewText:
Typing of the Dead: Overkill whilst still being a solid game has some glaring issues...

First the Good

+ Custom Dictionaries, Never ending content in your pursuit of mastering the keyboard, great addition.
+ Several mini games to keep content fresh.
+ Just as satisfying as ever to blow away zed by honing your typing skills.

The Bad.

- NO LOCAL MULTIPLAYER: As someone who does own PC light guns this is the first PC port of any HotD game to not have local multiplayer, just plain lazy... lazy... lazy. They also didn't take down the 'Player Two' scoreboard in singleplayer just to rub it in.
- Net code is terrible: 'Oh so no local means I can still enjoy it online right?' Wrong, the net coding is awful, I was playing with a friend that lives not half an hour away and it was an out of sync mess.
- Performance issues on windows 10: I cannot confirm this personally, but from what I have read online it simply does not work on windows 10.

reviewText:
This game is a total copy of the one people might have on their console (I have it on the wii). Still, its not so much a zombie shooter as it is a chance to practice your typing.
The game has you pumped and most of your concentration is focused on the words to type, rather than the zombie action going on. The harder levels are much tougher in that you need to type some strange punctuation symbols.

Its the sort of game that is not going to keep you engrossed for hours, but is perfect for filling in a 30 min gap you might have, and in playing, you feel like you are achieving something (improving your typing!)

reviewText:
The biggest value in this game is that it not only contains the Typing of the Dead, but the original rail shooter as well. It also has online play with a friend invite and random matching system.

The game is presented in the style of a series of B-movie trailers and offers a surprising amount of laughs. There is a plot, but it's more about the laughs than quality story telling.

As for actual gameplay, it's pretty much what you expect: words show up on the screen next to zom--er, mutants
date:
and you type the words to kill them. Apart from the quick single letter bonus enemies, typing words has the effect of body shots, giving you more time to finish typing a word after you start it. The game can still be difficult, however, as nerves can lead to slip ups that can give the enemies enough time to get at you, and the game does have a lot of jump-scare type events. Consecutive kills grant bonus points in both typing and rail shooter modes. You also get bonus points in typing mode by not making any mistakes during a word or phrase. There are bonuses scattered about the levels that make you have to pay attention to more than just words popping up on the screen, as they are unmarked and require a press of the tab key to obtain.

The rail shooter mode does not allow you to change the mouse sensitivity in-game, which is unfortunate as it is quite a bit slower than what I am used to. You do get used to it though. Head shots are one hit kills on most enemies and you receive bonus points for every 5 enemies you chain in such a manner. Current combo level is represented by a phrase and number of bullets in the chamber on the top left of the screen. Bonuses can be shot at and should be a priority as the camera moves soon after all enemies are defeated which can prevent you from grabbing them.

The game also features a number of multi-stage boss fights and mini-games. With all the game modes, humour, and online play for one low price, this makes quite a decent purchase.

Long version - spoilers ahead:

hoursPlayed: words and sentences in order to kill the mutants (see game screenshots). What I did not expect was that there is a fair element of strategy where you might surrender writing a long sentence to hit a couple of single keys as these tend to have a shorter time span before they hurt you. Some words are long and unusual forcing you to keep your eyes off the keyboard in order to see how they are spelled. The difficulties seem to be designed with progression in mind

reviewText: This game is brilliant. All the glorious cheesiness and hilarity mixed together with a rediculous plot. It's great to see how much work they put into the game and it comes with both the ORIGINAL House of the Dead and the Typing of the Dead. Plus minigames and multiplayer. The game is 3 bucks at Gamestop right now and you can't go wrong for that price. I constantly find myself laughing at the cutscenes, seeing a scientist have his glasses dramatically smacked off his face (notably cut and zoomed to in the scene) then immediatly returning the camera only to see another pair of glasses on his face.\n\nThe typing is fun and it's helping me improve my many typos, though I do accidentlly panic at times and backspace out of words when I type a wrong letter, so I still have a bit to adjust to. This is possibly one of the funniest games I've ever played, this is the one time I'll admit Game Misinformer got something right, if you're a Tarantino fan you'll probably love the ride. As long as you don't mind a massive amount of f-bombs being thrown in your face humorously I can't see how you can dislike this game.

reviewText:
Typing of the Dead: Overkill is a typing/rail shooter game, where you type phrases as quickly as possible to kill zombies. I've always kind of enjoyed typing games, and while I don't think this game has much merit in teaching you how to type properly, it's a fun game with an interesting sense of humor.

There's not too much to talk about with the gameplay. You type as quickly as possible, using Tab to pick up secrets and power-ups. What's more interesting to discuss with this game is how it's presented: as an old, low-budget horror movie. It tries very hard to be as cheesy as possible. Sometimes the phrases you type relate to the level you're playing, which gets pretty funny in the strip club level. This game is a bit lewd at times, and the swearing is excessive... not saying that's a bad thing, but it's something you should know going in to it.

Typing of the Dead: Overkill also includes House of the Dead: Overkill. The story is the same, but you play a standard rail shooter with normal controls instead of typing. I like switching between the two, just to change things up. House of the Dead is a little older, but as far as I know, this the only way to play the game on PC.

If a rail shooter or typing game sounds fun to you, then this would be a good game to pick up. There's a lot of content in this game, I don't think you'll be disappointed. Rail shooters and typing games aren't for everyone, and this game probably won't win you over to the genre (unless the movie aesthetic really appeals to you, I guess), but I've had a lot of fun with it so far, and I plan to keep playing it for a little while
