reviewText:
First of all, this game (Albeit it can be visually glitchy at times)is a dramatic upgrade over any other version of House of The Dead: Overkill, and seeing as you get both the typing and shooting variations of this game rolled into one, I'd say that's a good deal.

Now to my opinions, this game has an okay story for HoTD's standards with its cliché's and characters all being represented fairly well. Additionally the designs are just as you would expect from a HoTD game if not surpassing them in a positive way with the overal graphical designs and the boss designs to boot. The gameplay itself works out well, the typing is as responsive as your keyboard is and the mouse-aim shooting version plays just as well.

Also, the addition of Steam Workshop for fan-made dictionaries was a good move, but somewhat questionable given how we're offered dictionaries we have to pay for, that can be more than easily duplicated for free in the workshop? Not like I'm complaining, I still bought them to be supportive, that and I find Shakespearean language quite, interesting.

All in all, if you want a fun typing game, a typing enhancment tutor, or an on rail zombie shooter, Typing of The Dead: Overkill is a great choice.

reviewText:
So, it was not really clear to me what kind of game this was. But yes, it is a game where you kill zombies by......TYPING on your keyboard stuff that comes on the screen. If you are familiar with the house of the dead series (ever been to some arcade game center?), this is just as fun, with grindhouse style, funny dialogues etc. On pc is almost impossible to properly have a peripheral that simulates a gun (on PS you have PS move, on wii the wiimote...), so they chose they keyboard as a shooting device. It's LOTS of fun. I have a mechanical keyboard (Razer Blackwidow latest version) and it just looks like you're machine-gun-shooting letters in the face of the enemies. If you are a fast typer you will really enjoy the challenge. If you are a slow typer, you will enjoy it too, just will die more :D

Also reading the words that come on screen is fun because they may make you laugh from time to time. Funny stuff.

On the downside, the normal 'house of the dead' which is required anyway if you want to get all achievements, is boring as hell....shooting stuff with a mouse watching the cursor is not really entertaining......

Only CONS:

- they released different vocabularies (check the DLCs).....but each vocabulary is sold separately and is not very cheap. They should have released all the dictionaries in the normal release of the game, without limiting to one or two dictionnaries.

- the game renders at 720p whatever resolution you choose. Menus will look fine but the game engine output stays at 720p.

78/100 The Typing of the Dead
45/100 The House of the Dead (played with a mouse)

reviewText:
I think that the dialogue and style of this game are TERRIBLE. Some of the most overdone, pointless use of swearing ever. Don't get me wrong, I have no problem with swearing at all, but this game's use of it is so unneccesary that it goes BEYOND GRATUITOUS and begins to grate very quickly. The voice acting is also exceptionally bad, not just 'B-movie bad' like the game was probably aiming for.

The Grindhouse theme is kind of cool but again overdone and every level feels like a trailer from the prelude to Planet Terror.. cool for about 5 minutes.

Despite these misgivings though I keep coming back to this game because I think the type-to-kill mechanic is AWESOME.

I would much rather play the original Typing of the Dead game than this rebooted version, but beggars can't be choosers. 2/5

reviewText:
At first, I was torn on whether or not to give this game a positive or a negative review. After the game crashed on me at the end of a level, without saving my progress, I decided to write this negative review. Ok, here we go...

Graphics
-Sub-par graphics with crappy textures and cutscenes. For a game released in 2013, it sure looks alot like a game released in 2007.
+Runs at a steady 60 fps (which it should).
+Most cards can run this game smoothly.
-The game crashed a few times with no explaination.

Gameplay
+I LOVE the on-rails shooter style this game provides. It brings back the arcade nostalgia for me.
+The core concept of the game is incredibly fresh and fun. It's a great way to brush up on your typing speed.
+The words and phrases you will be typing are at times, hilarious. Examples include: Blue ♥♥♥♥, Cumquat Smuggler, Goat Curry, and Leper Handshake
-The characters are annoying as hell, and so is their back and forth banter. The characters themselves are cheesy and over-the-top (which I know is the point), but it gets really annoying.
-Bad humor EVERYWHERE. I curse like a sailor in my daily life, but Jesus Christ the language and humor was just over the top ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. It eventually got to the point where I just turned the game's master volume down and pulled up youtube in another window...thats how boring the story" is. And YES
date: there are a few times I found myself chuckling
hoursPlayed: the jokes were just plain dumb and cheesy as hell.\n-The voice acting from some of the characters in the game was terrible. Especially from one of the female characters
voteText: she just sounded unnatural when she cursed (like she was trying too hard).\n+There are boss battles at the end of each level
helpfulPercent: which is a nice touch. Unfortunately some bosses are just TOO easy
votesHelpful:
but overall the bosses were unique enough to keep me interested.
-The campaign is short. It took me 3.2 hours to beat the story mode on normal mode.
+Varying levels of difficulty can make the game challenging as hell.
+Zombies.

Story
-As stated before
votesTotal: the story is boring and uninteresting.\n+I do
votesFunny: however
commentsCount:
love the television show style of storytelling. I thought that was pretty original (and cheesy in a good way).
-Character development is lacking.

Conclusion
This game is fun

Awesome update on the typing game concept and has a very humourous dictionary (and dictionary DLC funciton!) but its ruined by the fact that it still does not make proper usage/scoring of SPACEBAR and CAPITOL letters. This game appears to be made by people who don't type in English and aren't aware of how important capitolization and spaces are. The game is essentially useless in learning to type ACCURATELY, as you can just smash the keyboard, type without spaces, and never capitolize without penalty.

Its obvious, but you should give players more options that allow them to customize how much accuracy they need; I want missed letters, spaces and capitol letters to count against the word (start over or backspace to fix). Also not every word needs to be capitolized... that's just silly and also not very useful.

needs a big update to the accuracy/scoring to make it compelling.

reviewText:
Originally released in 2009, House of the Dead: Overkill is a lightgun game inspired by grindhouse/exploitation cinema. Released on Steam, The Typing of the Dead: Overkill replaces the core gameplay with fast-paced typing mechanics. While the rerelease has been met with a certain amount of praise, Overkill has offensive content that you may want to know about before making a purchase.

-Frequent use of gendered insults. The easiest difficulty level is “♥♥♥♥♥”, a term thrown around throughout the game.
-Ableist and transphobic slurs. A character with a disability is described as a “cripple”; one of the in-game dictionary terms is “lady boy”.
-Prominent use of ethnic stereotypes.
-Women are defined by male gaze throughout.

reviewText:
Hilarious, over-the-top and downright offensive, this unique shooter is just ridiculous enough to be completely entertaining from start to finish.

I almost couldn’t believe the premise of this shooter when I first saw it. Really…you kill zombies by typing words correctly? Although I’ve admittedly not played the House of the Dead games outside of arcades, I felt like I couldn’t pass up this opportunity when I saw it. I’ve never played the original House of the Dead: Overkill either, although it is baked-in along with this new keyboard-based game.

As far as game mechanics go, it’s pretty much exactly what it advertises – words will pop up on the screen above zombies, and your success is based upon how quickly and accurately you can key in those words. Your characters move from room to room on rails, sometimes barreling through an entire squadron of undead, other times not moving forward until you’ve essentially committed zombie genocide. This is one of the few games in which I feel the DLC is needed, as it increases the dictionary of words used with interesting themes, such as a Shakespeare pack or a sports lexicon. Some of the words and phrases are absolutely wacky, and I loved the challenge it provided for both my fingers and my mind.

As for the story – that’s where the real charm of this game is found. The entire adventure is presented as a grindhouse-style flick, and there’s a filter over the action that shows film noise and burns, which I felt really set a tone right from the start. Every cutscene is appropriately ludicrous and crass; the main characters swear and curse with incredible conviction, which is actually addressed within the dialogue itself during the few quiet moments between levels. Traveling between setpieces, the characters will occasionally make a comment on their situation, or their relationship in regards to each other. It’s an incredibly honest approach to the standard zombie apocalypse gore fest, and at one point the male protagonists recognize that they are stereotypical macho men going who have to save the strongest female protagonist. I really wasn’t expecting a type-‘em-up zombie game to have an interesting, existential view of the genre as a whole, and yet there it was.

Otherwise, the game is comparatively offensive and comical as an episode of South Park. You’ll hear scat jokes as you attack a giant-headed, wheelchair-bound, Stephen-Hawking-esque zombie, for example. But, the game stays so consistent with how ham-fisted it is with being distasteful that it actually is engaging and fun throughout. Had the game attempted to be serious and grim, it would have failed miserably.

I did attempt to play the original House of the Dead: Overkill which is included, but the options for controller support is very scant. There’s no option to adjust the reticle sensitivity, and as a result I felt like the crosshairs were flying all over the screen, even during slow-motion sections. It feels like the typing aspect of this game is the main attraction, which certainly isn’t a bad thing.

I don’t know the next time that one of these House of the Dead typing games will be released, but I enjoyed my time with this one so much that I’ll probably grab whatever comes next as well. Recommended for anyone looking for something entirely new to the shooting genre.

reviewText:
I've never been a fan of the House of the Dead games. not because of the wanton gore, but because I'm not very good at them. I've never been happy holding guns - they make me nervous. And I'm a hopeless shot.

When I was given this as a present a few months ago, I thought I'd give it a go. It seems like an interesting gimmick, fighting by typing, and I liked the appeal of the grindhouse style. I didn't actually know it was related to the HotD games until I plasyed it.

What fun! Mavis Beacon Teaches Zombie Slaying. Or something. It's a lot more fun than the gimmick would suggest, and I played through the entire story the first time I played, just to see what outrageous things I'd be asked to spell next to dismember the charging undead. Now I have to go back and get some of the achievements I missed. I don't know if I'll be any good at standard mode" which uses the mouse
date: but I'm more than happy using the "typing" mode. Try it. Seriously. It sounds odd

reviewText:
The game is really fun, and if you like House of the Dead series, you will definitely love this one; and of course, you have to love typing on the keyboard too.

Graphics of the game is ok, for the rail shooting (typing) kind of game.  Gameplay is good.  Would have loved if they randomize more the words.  It seems to have like a set of words with a theme, and it gets repetitive (the words) when you play a lot.

Also, the game seems to not take Capital letters into account nor spacing.  Would be good if they granted bonus for using Shift key to type a capital letter, and space to separate the words.

I recommend this game to fans and typers.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Learn how to type... with ZOMBIES,In the saga of the House and Typing of the Dead series comes a compelling adventure of two foul-mouthed mother****ing heroes chasing a deranged madman known as Papa Ceasar who is causing all kinds of chaos unleashing hordes of crazy undead monstrosities upon innocents in this thrilla-in-Manilla excitement of an adventure to DIE for.

Cheesy intro aside, The Typing of the Dead: Overkill is just that: A (loosely) edutainment tool that has you typing out words to make zombies and other monsters DIE on-screen. Originally came out on the Wii as House of the Dead: Overkill, that game wound up re-released on the Playstation 3 with updated graphics and extra missions that tell a bigger story. And then the Steam version is a polished port of that, though with two games for the price of one (the original House of the Dead: Overkill comes with this).

Due to porting, yes, the graphics look pretty good, though one can tell it came from lower-end spectrum of graphics (though still look pretty decent). The gore factor (which the of the Dead series has been known for) is present, though could use a bit more... effect.

But obviously, this is a typing excercise where stringing together words and phrases nets you kills, and keeping mistakes to a minimum will jack-up ones score pronto.

Everything else from the previous Overkill experiences are still intact... lots of F-bombs flying, lots of over-the-top Grindhouse-esque sequences, lots of (zombified) strippers (for one level only), and plenty of fun that belies the fact that this game is a prequel to everything else within the of the Dead universe.

Can't go wrong with sharpening your typing skills while fending off something that wants to eat your face.

I've never played a light gun game on PC before this, but the smooth and excellent control configuration for the mouse makes me wonder why we don't see more of this genre on Steam.\n\nIf you're looking for some insane zombie killing while you type away, look no further.

reviewText:
Let's shoot the elephant in the room first, guys.  In terms of language, premise, and treatment of female characters - this game is a full 31 different flavors of wrong.  It puts the over the top grindhouse aesthetic into an Indy Jones minecart and sends it careening down the tracks at breakneck speed to burst through a wall already starting to explode with 5 tons of C4. That's how flat out wrong it is.   Consider yourself duly warned if you're unfamiliar with Overkill from the real world setting.

That said : I'm a fan of the Typing of the Dead treatments of the House of the Dead games.  I bought this largely on the strength of the first 'Typing of the Dead' experience, which was good silly zombie killing fun.  I'm a fairly accurate typist, so it was fun diversion and I was glad to see more of the same available on Steam.

So do we have zombies to kill? Check.

Do we have absurd and fun things to type to kill the zombies? Check.

Are there lots of them? Check. There are indeed. Several container ship's worth of zombies to kill.  All kinds of check.

Entertaining boss battles?    Semi-check.  So-so. The original Typing of the Dead''s boss fights took the absurdist typing up a few notches
date: giving you full sentences to type to inflict damage.  Overkill's boss battles are largely more standard zombie kill words with a fancy setpiece. So that was a little disappointing.  I will say this
recommended: though - the boss mechanic does get changed up entertainingly for the final conflict. That one I enjoyed.\n\nDo we see our protagonists running around with comedy keyboards to type on hanging from their necks?  Sadly - no
hoursPlayed: we do not.\n\nDo we have the option to use the mouse as a targeting reticule?  Well

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
While not being anywhere near as psychotic an idea as the original Typing of The Dead, Overkill is still loads of fun.

The original ToTD integrated the typing element directly into every aspect of the game, whereas here it's basically just a barebones typing game. This unfortunately means no cutscenes where your agents run around the streets with giant keyboards strapped to their chests.

Putting that aside, this is a fun light-gun shooter with mouse support for those finger-peckers, slow-typists and everyone else who developed carpal tunnel syndrome from the home row keys.

Just when you think you've mastered the game, newer more challenging modes open up for extended replay value.

Definitely recommended for anyone who enjoys swearing, blowing away freaks and mutants and copious amounts of suggestive innuendo.

reviewText: This is, without a doubt, the best money I have ever spent on Steam. Not only is this game hilarious and fun, it's educational. That is right folks, I said education AND fun. Typing of the Dead takes everything that is great about grindhouse films and smashes it together with the Zombie genre.\n\nWith a multiple game modes, new languages and difficulty modes there is an endless amount of replayability. reviewText:
I've never been a fan of the House of the Dead games. not because of the wanton gore, but because I'm not very good at them. I've never been happy holding guns - they make me nervous. And I'm a hopeless shot.

When I was given this as a present a few months ago, I thought I'd give it a go. It seems like an interesting gimmick, fighting by typing, and I liked the appeal of the grindhouse style. I didn't actually know it was related to the HotD games until I plasyed it.

What fun! Mavis Beacon Teaches Zombie Slaying. Or something. It's a lot more fun than the gimmick would suggest, and I played through the entire story the first time I played, just to see what outrageous things I'd be asked to spell next to dismember the charging undead. Now I have to go back and get some of the achievements I missed. I don't know if I'll be any good at standard mode" which uses the mouse

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I loved the hell out of the original DreamCast TOTD back in the day, and in a rare move, actually bought this one around release time, at full price. In the strictest sense, it is a Typing of the Dead game: you type words and not-zombie zombies go splat. However, Overkill lacks a lot of the goofy charm that made the original so memorable and enjoyable, and it's not just that G and Isaac aren't running around with laptops strapped to their backs and keyboards floating in front of them. It's possible that part of the problem is that the joke only works once, but I think the bigger issue is that, well, it's based on House of the Dead: Overkill.

There's frankly nothing likeable whatsoever about Overkill. The dialogue is insipid and juvenile, and can only partially be avoided by skipping cutscenes. Everything about the visual design is grotesque, even by the standards of a zombie game, in a way that's off-putting rather than atmospheric. The plot is pure nonsense, and that's not entirely unexpected, that doesn't make the stupidity and/or grossness of everyone involved any less obnoxious. The '70s-inspired music that came packed in with the grindhouse aesthetic is the only real saving grace, and even at that, there are several tracks ruined by the invasion of the aforementioned dialogue, and I couldn't find a way to skip those tracks in favour of something more listenable. And since I have nothing nice to say about the portrayal and treatment of the female characters, I'll instead say, nothing."

As I said
date: I came into TOTD: Overkill really wanting to like it. I figured I'd be replaying all the levels on the highest difficulty
voteText: maybe going through it co-op
helpfulPercent: too. Instead
votesHelpful: I hit Delete Local Content the minute the campaign reached its mercifully swift end. TOTD: Overkill was neither fun nor funny
votesTotal: and I can't find a single compelling reason to recommend it. Go play the original instead."

reviewText:
If you have played the original typing of the dead, you would know what to expect of this game. For those of you who have not, it's a shoot-em-up, but rather than a gun (or a mouse pointer) you type words to kill the zombie/mutants.

It's a decent game, yeah, but still, not that much engaging in terms of the typing, just, spam the words, mash the keyboard, wazoom, bang, zap, kill dem zombies. If you have played the first ToTD, it's definitely superior in terms of how much more engaging the gameplay was (e.g. those question prompts, they were gone, somewhat, at least in the levels that I have completed). So killing those bosses is just a matter of typing accurately and typing fast. I could've sworn that the level design seemed to be more linear and doesn't offer that much of a branching paths as well.

But to say that this is a bad game would be a lie, it's decent, but nowhere near as good as the first. For the price, I'd reccomend to wait til it is on discount, rather than buying the thing at $20.

...oh and, bad voice acting lingers like a charm in the HoTD series, inclusive of this one...

reviewText:
Several things annoyed me with this game:
- Humour felt forced and got old quick.
- Cutscenes drag on for too long. (beacuse who really cares about the story here?)
- General pacing problems. (not much fun in just watching your character tumble around, just waiting for the next word to pop up)
- Unimaginative boss fights. (only the final one was a variation from the rest of the game, and you could beat it by just hammering on all keys at once)

Compared to the other Typing of the Dead game, this one seemed to be all about style instead of substance. Still recommending it, as it in spite of its problem is a fun way to improve your keyboard-typing skills.

reviewText:
The game is quite fun and offers unique gameplay mechanics utilizing typing to advance the game. It seems like a nice way to teach kids words and spelling (assuming you can ignore the gore and blood involved in the process).

At its base the game consists of two gameplay modes. The first is where you type random words attached to mutant zombies in order to kill them. The second mode is more akin to the old arcade game machines where enemies appear on-screen and you aim the gun to shot (meaning you can't move, you just shot what appears when it appears). Both modes can be adjusted for its difficulty levels (longer-harder words and etc).

The story and mood of the game is set as a 1970's B-movie and while cliched (as expected) is quite entertaining. To add a little spice, you can pick various collectibles scattered throughout the different levels in the form of a comic-book, concept art, posters, audio tracks and 3d character models. Also, in case you have become bored with the choice of words present there are several dictionary-themed DLCs you can buy, ranging from movies and novellas to just plain filth.

Be advised though, at first the game seemed to have bug with Steam overlay. For some reason it got resolved by itself the next day (maybe a restart after installation of game/redist was in order, but it didn't ask for one). There were also mentions of black-screen issues (I think it got fixed) on the game forum so might wanna check that beforehand.

Long story short, get it. Even just as a guilty pleasure for the B-movie story if not for the unique mechanics.

reviewText: Unlike most games, the buyer should have a good idea of what he or she is getting here: it's a typing game.  If you want to improve your typing speed, or just enjoy typing, then you'll love this typing-software-with-a-zombie-wrapper.  There is slightly more to this game than that, though: it has very cheesy, but funny, cut scenes, the words you type can be very hilarious, and the overkill edition allows you to shoot using a mouse {like other on-rail shooters).\n\nYou can pick and choose which DLC you want activated at a time, and also choose the frequency with which the DLC dictionaries appear (up to 100%).  There are mini-games included, too.  All in all, it's a good game that will hold up well over time, as you'll be playing it for typing exercise more than anything. reviewText:
Even as a remake of the original HOTD: Overkill, this game screams of a spectacularly low budget, stilted, schlocky writing, and and all-around mindless mishmash of gore.
It's also tight as HELL and an all-around damn fun game! The game sells itself as an old-style buddy-cop action flick, and it's cheesy and stupid as they come. Headstrong Games/Modern Dream rocks it 100%, even going so far as to criticize its own schlocky writing by the endgame.
The gameplay itself is actually surprisingly tight, you type at zombies and they die in bloody clouds. You can pick up some powerups and collectables along the way, and the little quips that you type out can be pretty entertaining, complimenting the goofiness of the game's setting overall.
Get it while it's cheap!

reviewText: I came into this game really having little experience with these rail-shooter" types of games.  The only shooters I had really played are FPSes like Doom and Painkiller
date: which of course let you choose your own path through a level.\n\nI was intrigued by the concept from the first time I read about it: A shooter that allows you to literally type your foes into submission.  I wasn't totally sure what to expect and was somewhat skeptical when I first started playing
recommended: but the end result is actually a lot of fun.  The designers did a great job of adapting such shooter mechanics to the keyboard
hoursPlayed: giving each enemy you encounter a series of "kill words" that you must type correctly to defeat your opponent.  The color of the border around the word or phrase to be typed determines that enemy's level of threat.  A green border suggests that the enemy poses little threat
voteText: whereas a red border means imminent danger.\n\nFor the most part
helpfulPercent: the mechanics work very well.  As you type a word correctly
votesHelpful: the letters fade out
votesTotal: and you can both hear and see gunshots striking the targeted opponent.  If you need to switch to another target
votesFunny: a quick tap of Backspace cancels the word you were typing completely
commentsCount: allowing to start typing the word of the new target.  Gratefully
column16: you can make a mistake in typing without starting a word or phrase over again unless you turn on Hardcore mode after beating the game once.  You can also make a mistake without losing your combo point bonus.  The designers were respectful of players who may be somewhat frantic in their typing first starting out so as not to cause frustration for making mistakes
column17: and there are three difficulty levels to make it fun for everyone.  Even the boss fights have for the most part been well adapted to this format
column18: with series of words and phrases used to not only injure the boss
column19: but also to do things like destroy projectiles
column20: interrupt attacks
column21: and dodge out of the way of an oncoming charge.  The game also gives you fun stats after each level
column24: and longest combo.  You're also given a letter ranking based on your overall performance; can you earn an "A" on every course?  That's what I'm working on now.\n\nOf course
column25: some adjustments had to be made from the normal shooting format.  Weapon power-ups are not available
column26: for example.  You don't earn cash for stronger weapons
column27: and there are no grenades or cash pick-ups present.  This doesn't have much of an impact
column29: as you'll be having too much fun typing out the crazy kill words and expressions the game throws at you.  One fault I did have is with picking up items such as Med-Kits and collectibles.  There's only a very brief tutorial in the first level to outline the use of the Tab key to nab such items
column30: and it appears to be completely omitted from the instruction manual.  A few deaths I suffered during my initial playthrough could have been eliminated had this been made more clear.\n\nI honestly didn't have very much to complain about with this game.  My biggest complaint is with the final battle.  I won't spoil it
column32: the rules of that battle are completely inane
column33: and I suffered an extremely high number of deaths before winning
column34: in part because I couldn't find a way to inflict much damage or stop oncoming attacks as I did with every other boss.  Let's just say that this battle is much more free-form than the rest of the game.  Additionally
column35: while I found very little in the way of bugs in the game
column36: I do occasionally have sound effects and voices drop out completely
column37: especially when repelling the attacks of mutants who grapple with your character to try and bite you.\n\nMy only other gripe with the game is with the constant profanity.  Yes
column38: I realize this is a game primarily designed to shock and possibly offend
column39: and the characters cursing was not surprising.  The LEVEL of profanity
column41: is something new to me; Washington and Varla Guns especially cannot say the "F" word enough throughout this game
column42: and I found such overuse of profanity a little too gratuitous
column43: and it also detracts from the overall narrative.  In some places
column45: such as during the ending when Washington's personality starts to rub off on Agent G.  Other times
column46: I kept thinking that the writers could have given them SOMETHING else to say.\n\nIn other areas
column48: the presentation hits the mark.  There's some excellent and clever alliteration by the narrator in the cutscenes
column49: which are basically presented like horror movie trailers
column50: and this gives an interesting new take on the traditional cutscene format.  The graphics are well detailed
column51: and some of the bosses especially are truly grotesque and imaginative in their design.\n\nAs a bonus treat
column52: the original The House of the Dead: Overkill is included with this game as well
column53: utilizing either the mouse or a controller to aim your weapons at the mutant hordes.  You have full grenade support here and a full complement of weapon upgrades to purchase as the game progresses.  Your weapon selection is critical in some stages and can either give you a boost fighting a boss or render you completely ineffective.  I found the mouse controls to be very responsive and this version of the game to be fun
column54: though the typist in me almost prefers that version.  This is simply a matter of taste
column56: and being able to play both games in one release is a great decision by the designers and lets everyone play however they want.  One side note: The final boss was MUCH easier in this mode

reviewText:
Typing has never been so fun!

The whole game plays like a cheesy 90's movie. The dialogue is funny as hell, the story and characters are over-the-top and the zombies are deliciously disgusting, so it's a pleasure to make their heads explode. And it's also kind of two games in one - the typing version and the classical one, where you aim and shoot with your mouse or controller. Other than that it's the same story, only the controls are different. It also contains plenty of unlockables and minigames, so it will last you for a while. And best of all, it actually teaches you to type faster! Who said video games cannot be useful?

Pros:

- Game is too easy once weapons are upgraded to its maximum capacity
- No local co-op; super lame!

Replay Value: 0.5 Star
Overall: 1 Star

reviewText:
Sup, Steam? I just got back from a playthrough of The Typing of the Dead: Overkill by SEGA. Three words: hella f*cking epic.

I played with some friends and I don't think we went more than 10 seconds without standing up clapping. I mean what can I say about SEGA that already hasn't? They're game gods.


This is, without a doubt, my favorite game of the year so far (and arguably the greatest typing game of all time) so I highly suggest you and some friends go out and buy it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: If I explained this game to anyone they'd never buy it. Parody of an over the top B-movie, on-the-rails-fps, arcade machine played by typing onscreen words. It sounds stupid, but it's a barrel of laughs! I got it in a humble bundle and would recommend it to anyone looking for a laugh.\n\nCheap, fun, overly violent, unnecessary levels of swearing and it's educational. What else do you need to hear?

reviewText: Cheesy, goofy and possibly the most stupidly awesome game ever. Includes the regular House of the Dead: Overkill, so you can shoot them zom-mutants if you like, too!\n\nThe typing mechanic fits really well the parodic B-movie feel of the game, turning the fun up to 11. Absolutely hilarious!
